Title: Using a high precision programmable DC power supply of TPS magnet
Affiliations: NSRRC, Hsinchu 30076, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Wong, Y.-S., NSRRC, Hsinchu 30076, Taiwan; Liu, K.-B., NSRRC, Hsinchu 30076, Taiwan; Huang, J.-C., NSRRC, Hsinchu 30076, Taiwan; Wen, W.-S., NSRRC, Hsinchu 30076, Taiwan
Abstract: Taiwan government had been announcement to set up a third-generation synchrotron radiation light source in February 2010. It should be installed with 1032 sets of magnet power supplies for the storage ring and 152 sets for the injector. In the storage ring, high precision DC power supply for 48 quadrupole magnets , 240 quadrupole magnets and 168 sextupole magnets [1]. The main windings of quadrupole and sextupole magnets are powered by individual power supplies. In the booster rings, one set of dynamic power supply for the quadrupole magnets and four sets for quadrupole magnets run at the biased 3Hz quasi sinusoidal wave. The Taiwan photon source (TPS) plan was completed indication national synchrotron radiation research central (NSRRC) technical capability to build at its present site in seven years a 3~3.3 GeV electron energy, 518 meter circumference, low-emittance synchrotron storage ring which will offer one of the world's brightest synchrotron x-ray sources, provide cutting-edge experimental facilities and novel multidisciplinary scientific research opportunities, enhance world-class academic research, as well as create Taiwan's scientific research marvels in the twenty-first century. Copyright © 2011 by IPAC'11/EPS-AG.
Index Keywords: Experimental facilities; Magnet power supply; Quadrupole magnets; Scientific researches; Synchrotron radiation light source; Synchrotron storage ring; Synchrotron x rays; Technical capabilities; Research; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Magnets

Authors: Harasimowicz J., Welsch C.P., Fernandez-Hernando J.L., Cosentino L., Finocchiaro P., Pappalardo A.
Title: Thin foil-based secondary emission monitor for low intensity, low energy beam profile measurements
Affiliations: Cockcroft Institute, University of Liverpool, United Kingdom; STFC, DL ASTeC, Cockcroft Institute, Daresbury, United Kingdom; INFN-LNS, Catania, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Harasimowicz, J., Cockcroft Institute, University of Liverpool, United Kingdom; Welsch, C.P., Cockcroft Institute, University of Liverpool, United Kingdom; Fernandez-Hernando, J.L., STFC, DL ASTeC, Cockcroft Institute, Daresbury, United Kingdom; Cosentino, L., INFN-LNS, Catania, Italy; Finocchiaro, P., INFN-LNS, Catania, Italy; Pappalardo, A., INFN-LNS, Catania, Italy
Abstract: A foil-based secondary emission monitor (SEM) was developed for beam profile measurements at the Ultra-low energy Storage Ring (USR) that will be installed at the future Facility for Low-energy Antiproton and Ion Research (FLAIR) in Darmstadt, Germany. Simulations of the optimised design of the monitor are presented. Furthermore, its usability for the low energy antiproton (p) beam profile monitoring is discussed. Authors: Zhu W.H., Zhu Y., Tatarchuk B.J.
Title: Comparison of on-board hydrogen production from several non-fossil fuel feedstocks
Affiliations: Center for Microfibrous Materials, Department of Chemical Engineering, Auburn University, Auburn, AL, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering, Auburn University, Auburn, AL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, W.H., Center for Microfibrous Materials, Department of Chemical Engineering, Auburn University, Auburn, AL, United States; Zhu, Y., Department of Chemical Engineering, Auburn University, Auburn, AL, United States; Tatarchuk, B.J., Department of Chemical Engineering, Auburn University, Auburn, AL, United States
Abstract: In comparison with other types of fuel cells, the PEFC is compact and lightweight because of its better volumic-power and power density characteristics. It usually works at a temperature range from 40°C to 90°C. On the other hand, the high-temperature PEFC operating from 120-180°C is suitable for H 2 fuel produced by fuel processors, because of its CO tolerance up to 3%. These features make it suitable for automotive applications due to requirement of fast dynamic response to the speed and power-need change. But liquid hydrogen fuel faces many challenges such as transportation and on-board H 2 energy storage. This work compares and discusses in details for potential methods on-board H 2 production from non-fossil fuel feedstocks, such as ammonia and methanol fuels, which is useful for low or high-temperature PEFC on-board applications. Hydrogen fuel from fuel processors is one of the solutions to on-board energy storage because of the high cost and risk of liquid hydrogen or metal hydride storage. Hydrogen fuels from non-fossil fuel feedstocks are normally from water /ammonia /methanol electrolysis, methanol steam reforming, or reforming of bio-fuels. Due to the difficulties of hydrogen storage and transportation, ammonia and methanol are two of preferred choices of hydrogen fuel sources for low-temperature or high-temperature PEFC applications because of their existing production, storage, and transport technologies.

Authors: Abrahamson J.T., Song C., Hu J.H., Forman J.M., Mahajan S.G., Nair N., Choi W., Lee E.-J., Strano M.S.
Title: Energy storage and generation from thermopower waves: covalently functionalized thermal and electrical conduits
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Department of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon, South Korea; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abrahamson, J.T., Department of Chemical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Song, C., Department of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon, South Korea; Hu, J.H., Department of Chemical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Forman, J.M., Department of Chemical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Mahajan, S.G., Department of Chemical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Nair, N., Department of Chemical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Choi, W., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Lee, E.-J., Department of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon, South Korea; Strano, M.S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Abstract: We have demonstrated through simulation and experiment that the nonlinear coupling between an exothermic chemical reaction and a nanowire or nanotube with large axial heat conduction accelerates the thermal reaction wave along the nano-conduit. The thermal conduit rapidly transports energy to unreacted fuel regions, and the reaction wave induces a concomitant thermopower wave of high power density, producing electrical current in the same direction. At up to 7 W/g, this can be substantially larger than the power density offered by current micro-scale power sources (e.g. fuel cells, batteries) and even about seven times greater than that of commercial Li-ion batteries. MEMS devices and wireless sensor networks would benefit from such high power density sources to enable functions such as communications and acceleration hampered by present power sources. Recently, we have covalently attached energetic molecules of mono-, di-, and trinitrobenzenes to single-walled carbon nanotubes via diazonium chemistry. Although covalent functionalization introduces defects that can scatter electrons and phonons, thermopower waves can still rapidly propagate and produce electricity on these decorated nanotubes. Differential scanning calorimetry confirms that the energetic molecules release heat, but thermopower waves require additional fuel adsorbed on the nanotubes to propagate.

Authors: Zhang X., Tande B.
Title: Regeneration of CO 2 solvents with polymeric membranes
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, X., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, United States; Tande, B., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, United States
Abstract: The capture and storage of CO 2 is considered a potential mitigation to global climate change caused by greenhouse gases. Extensive research has been conducted to develop membrane-based systems for CO2 capture from fixed sources, such as coal-fired power plants, due to the operational simplicity, reliability, and energy efficiency of membranes. Rather than focus on CO 2 capture directly from flue gas, our work seeks to evaluate membranes as a means to regenerate CO 2 from absorption solvents such as monoethanolamine (MEA). A membrane evaluation system was designed and built to study the permeability and selectivity of various membrane materials for the recovery of CO2 from MEA solutions. The feed consisted of an aqueous MEA solution (15% wt) saturated with CO2 and continuously circulated through a membrane module. On the permeate side of the membrane a sweep gas was used to maintain a low CO 2 partial pressure. The permeate gas composition was measured by gas chromatography (GC) and a non-dispersive infrared (NDIR) detector. The performance of several porous and nonporous membrane materials, including polyester (PE), polypropylene (PP), polyamide, and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), was measured and compared. The effects of feed flow rate, sweep gas rate, and temperature on CO 2 permeability were studied, as was the ability of these membranes to perform in long-term, continuous operation. Membrane porosity, swelling, and surface morphology was characterized by optical and electron microscopy.

Authors: Zhao X., Hayner C.M., Kung M.C., Kung H.H.
Title: Engineered Si-graphene composite papers with enhanced lithium ion transport for high-power batteries
Affiliations: Chemical and Biological Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhao, X., Chemical and Biological Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Hayner, C.M., Chemical and Biological Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Kung, M.C., Chemical and Biological Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Kung, H.H., Chemical and Biological Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States
Abstract: The development of more efficient energy conversion and storage devices remains a pressing need in attempting to achieve a high level of market penetration of electric vehicles and use of intermittent renewable energy sources such as wind and solar energy. Current lithium-ion batteries, although an attractive energy storage device, have limited charge capacity that diminishes rapidly at high charge/discharge rates. We have shown previously that a Si-graphene composite integrated into a 3-dimensional, conducting graphitic network offers high structural and cycling stability and substantially higher charge capacity as an anode material than graphite. However, the composite suffers from the problem of diminishing charge capacity during high current operations. Here, we report a facile microscopic engineering strategy to enhance the Li ion transport in graphene sheets, which could be utilized as a platform to create high-power battery materials. When used with Si nanoparticles to form a Si-graphene composite and integrating the composite into a 3-dimensional graphitic network to form a self-supporting electrode paper, the electrode exhibits an outstanding energy density-power density combination, without compromising the usable lifetime and mechanical flexibility. The power capability was found to be comparable to supercapacitors but with a much higher energy density. For example, a charge capacity of over 1000 mAh/g was achieved at a discharge rate of 8 A/g. Structural characterization by high resolution electron microscopy and impedance measurements provided evidence that relates the structural properties to the Li ion diffusivity for this material, which can bridge the performance disparity between batteries with high energy density and capacitors with high power density.

Authors: You F., Wang B.
Title: Optimal design and operations of cellulosic biofuel supply chains under uncertainty
Affiliations: Dept. of Chemical Engineering, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: You, F., Dept. of Chemical Engineering, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Wang, B., Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States
Abstract: Concerns about climate change, energy security, and the diminishing supply of fossil fuels are causing our society to search for new renewable sources of transportation fuels. Domestically available biomass has been proposed as part of the solution to our dependence on fossil fuels. Biofuels, especially liquid transportation fuels produced from cellulosic materials, have the benefits of significantly reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and leading to new jobs and greater economic vitality in rural areas. Renewable Fuels Standard (RFS), part of the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007, establishes a target of 16 billion gallons of cellulosic biofuel annual production by 2022, although the United States produced less than 1 billion gallons of liquid fuels from cellulosic materials in 2010. In observance of this mandatory production target, many new cellulosic biomass-to-biofuels supply chains will be designed and developed in the coming decade for better economic, environmental and social performances. However, uncertainty resulting from supply and demand variations may have significant impact on the biofuel supply chain. Therefore, an efficient optimization strategy is urgently needed to for the design and operations of sustainable and robust cellulosic biofuel supply chains. In this work, we address the optimal design and planning of cellulosic biofuel supply chains under supply and demand uncertainty. A two-stage stochastic mixed-integer linear programming (SMILP) model combined with Monte Carlo sampling and the associated statistical analysis is proposed to deal with different types of uncertainty, and it is incorporated into a multi-period planning model that takes into account the main characteristics of the biofuel supply chains, such as seasonality of feedstock supply, biomass deterioration with time, geographical diversity and availability of biomass resources, feedstock density, diverse conversion technologies and byproducts, infrastructure compatibility, demand distribution, regional economic structure, and government incentives. In the two-stage framework, the supply chain network design and capacity planning decisions are made "here-and-now" prior to the resolution of uncertainty, while the production, transportation and storage decisions for each time period are postponed in a "wait-and-see" mode. The SMILP model integrates decision making across multiple temporal and spatial scales and simultaneously predicts the optimal network design, facility location, technology selection, capital investment, production operations, inventory control, and logistics management decisions. In order to solve the resulting large scale SMILP problems effectively, a decomposition algorithm based on sampling average approximation and multi-cut L-shaped method is proposed by taking advantage of the problem structure. In addition to the economic objective of minimizing the annualized net present cost, the SMILP model is also extended to integrate with life cycle assessment (LCA) and regional economic input-output (EIO) analysis through a multiobjective optimization scheme to include two other objectives: the environmental objective measured by life-cycle greenhouse gas emissions and the social objective measured by the number of accrued local jobs resulting from the construction and operation of the cellulosic biofuel supply chain. The multiobjective optimization framework allows the model to establish tradeoffs among the economic, environmental, and social performances of the cellulosic biofuel supply chains in a systematic way. The multiobjective optimization problem is solved with an ?-constraint method and produces Pareto-optimal curves that reveal how the optimal annualized cost and the supply chain network structure change with different environmental and social performance of the entire supply chain. The proposed optimization model and solution method is illustrated through county-level case study for the state of Illinois. Three major types of biomass, including crop residues, energy crops, and wood residues, and three major conversion pathways, including biochemical conversion, gasification followed by Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and fast pyrolysis followed by hydroprocessing are considered. Uncertainty information is generated from the time series analysis based on the historical data of biomass feedstock supply and liquid fuel demand. County-level results will be presented that provide regionally-based insight into transition pathways of biomass production and conversion. Computational results also demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed decomposition algorithm for the solution of large-scale SMILP problems.

Authors: Li Y., Wang W., Kim S., Murugesan V., Nie Z., Chen B., Luo Q., Chen F., Liu J., Hu J., Yang G.
Title: Development of new redox flow battery systems
Affiliations: Hydrocarbon Processing Group, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Li, Y., Hydrocarbon Processing Group, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Wang, W., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Kim, S., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Murugesan, V., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Nie, Z., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Chen, B., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Luo, Q., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Chen, F., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Liu, J., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Hu, J., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Yang, G., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Abstract: Concerns over the environmental consequences of burning fossil fuels and their remaining reserves have led to an increasing use of renewable energy generated from sources such as solar and wind. However, the intermittent, varied nature of the renewable resources makes it difficult to integrate these valuable energies into the electrical grids. A solution to this problem is to employ large-scale electrical energy storage (EES), which is widely considered as an effective approach to improve the reliability, power quality, and economy of these renewable energies. Among the most promising large-scale EES technologies are the redox flow batteries (RFBs). RFBs are special electrochemical systems that can repeatedly convert and store multi-megawatt-hours (MWhs) of electricity energy to chemical energy and convert the chemical energy back to electricity energy when needed. The advantages of RFBs include short response time, low self discharge, long life-time, and independent tunable power and storage capacity, which make it possible to independently scale up the electricity storage capacity and power generation capacity. With the support of US Department of Energy's Office of Electricity, PNNL has carried out extensive efforts in the development of advanced redox flow batteries. Substantial progress has been achieved in the past two years, including two new redox chemistries (V-Fe system and all vanadium mixed acid system), which will be reported in this presentation.

Authors: Feng X., Zhuang W., Lu L., Zhu Y., Wu X., Meng M., Lu X.
Title: Significant enhancement of lithium intercalation into mesoporous titania with trace TiO 2-B on surface
Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Materials-oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing, China
Authors with affiliations: Feng, X., State Key Laboratory of Materials-oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing, China; Zhuang, W., State Key Laboratory of Materials-oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing, China; Lu, L., State Key Laboratory of Materials-oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing, China; Zhu, Y., State Key Laboratory of Materials-oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing, China; Wu, X., State Key Laboratory of Materials-oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing, China; Meng, M., State Key Laboratory of Materials-oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing, China; Lu, X., State Key Laboratory of Materials-oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing, China
Abstract: TiO 2 is expected to play an important role in addressing the problems of clean energy supply and global warming on account of its promising applications in photovoltaics, photocatalytic oxidation and splitting of water. It is well recognized that in order to implement these applications, TiO 2 should own a large surface area, a high crystallinity and high thermal stability simultaneously. Our group has developed a template-free method to fabricate mesoporous Titania (m-TiO 2) nanofibers with all these properties. Trace TiO 2-B was proved by high resolution transmission electron microscopy and Raman spectra. However, its contribution in terms of performance was not perfectly specified. In this work, we report on lithium-ion intercalation/deintercalation reaction in two differrent m-TiO 2 with or without trace TiO 2-B and find significant intercalation increasement of m-TiO 2 with trace TiO 2-B on surface. TiO 2-B is a metastable monoclinic polymorph of TiO 2 different from anatase. Its open structure, characterized as large and continuous channels, makes it well suited as a host for Li+ ion intercalation. It can be seen that the cyclic voltammetry of m-TiO 2 exhibits a pair of cathodic/anodic peaks at 1.70 and 2.05V, which are attributed to lithium-ion intercalation/deintercalation reaction in anatase phase. In addition to that, the voltammogram of m-TiO 2 with trace TiO 2-B shows another two pairs of peaks with formal potentials in the range of 1.5-1.6 V vs. Li +/Li, respectively. This notation can be assigned to the reaction of lithium-ion intercalation/ deintercalation reaction in TiO 2-B phase lattice. The first discharge capacity of m-TiO 2 with trace TiO 2-B can reach up to 247 mA·h·g-1 at the current rate of 130 mA·g-1 which is about 50 mA·h·g-1 higher than that of m-TiO 2 without TiO 2-B. Stable cycling discharge capacity attains 170 mA·h·g-1 at the discharge rate of 155 mA·g -1 and 110 mA·h·g -1 even up to 4000 mA·g -1. These findings indicate that m-TiO 2 with trace TiO 2-B on surface represents a promising material in lithium ion delivery and storage.

Authors: Wang C., Zhu Y.
Title: Novel electroanalytical techniques for phase transformation electrodes
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Maryland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, C., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Maryland, United States; Zhu, Y., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Maryland, United States
Abstract: A discussion on new electroanalytical techniques for phase transformation electrodes covers interface mobility; accommodation energy; electrode materials for high power Li-ion batteries; enabling technology for electric vehicle/hybrid electric vehicles and renewable energy storage; Strain accommodation energy of LiFePO 4 during charge and discharge in two phase region; and true Li-ion diffusion coefficients. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 2011 AIChE Annual Meeting (Minneapolis, MN 10/16-21/2011).

Authors: Chou C.-C., Liu C.-H., Chen B.-H., Lee D.-J.
Title: Hydrogen production from deliquescence of ammonia borane
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan; Department of Chemical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chou, C.-C., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan; Liu, C.-H., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan; Chen, B.-H., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan; Lee, D.-J., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan
Abstract: Chemical hydride is one of the most potential hydrogen storage materials which can effectively increase hydrogen storage capacity. To meet the new goal of U.S. department of energy (DoE), 4.5wt% and 5.5 wt% of gravimetric hydrogen density capacity by 2010 and 2015, respectively, ammonia borane (AB) is an attractive material due to high intrinsic hydrogen density (i.e. 19.6 wt%). Such a high intrinsic hydrogen density increases the possibility to apply to be the on-board power source of vehicle system, not only for 3C electric product. In this study, hydrogen evolution from hydrolysis of ammonia borane in limiting water conditions is studied. The solid composite of ammonia borane hydrogen fuel is synthesized with pulverized catalyst through the high energy ball milling process. Various parameters such as the amount of water dosage, temperature, loading of catalysts, on hydrogen production characteristics will be discussed. Kinetic behavior of the hydrolysis reaction in such limiting water supply conditions will also be investigated. Based on experimental outcomes, optimal conditions on hydrogen production from this hydrogen storage system will be proposed.

Authors: Lin J.-S., Chang H., Wang G.-B.
Title: Modeling and control of the solar powered membrane distillation system
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, Chang Gung University, Tao-Yuan 33302, Taiwan; Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, Energy and Opto-Electronic Materials Research Center, Tamkang University, Taipei 25137, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lin, J.-S., Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, Chang Gung University, Tao-Yuan 33302, Taiwan; Chang, H., Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, Energy and Opto-Electronic Materials Research Center, Tamkang University, Taipei 25137, Taiwan; Wang, G.-B., Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, Chang Gung University, Tao-Yuan 33302, Taiwan
Abstract: Solar radiation can be transferred to thermal energy by collectors and used to solar thermal energy systems. There are many potentially commercial advantages to use seawater desalination systems driven by solar power. The dynamic modeling and process control of a solar powered membrane distillation system is studied. Direct contact membrane distillation (DCMD) is considered in the proposed solar powered MD system. The mathematical models of solar collector, thermal storage tanks, heat exchanger, MD module, and fresh water storage tank are built on MATLAB platform. The simulation results demonstrate the effective performance of the proposed control loops for the solar powered MD systems. Two temperature control loops are put forward. The feasible PI controller parameters for the solar powered MD systems are also presented. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 2011 AIChE Annual Meeting (Minneapolis, MN 10/16-21/2011).

Authors: Kim Y., Ko J., Hong Y.-J., Lee K.H.
Title: Design for a medium to small-scale hydrogen liquefaction plant
Affiliations: Energy Plant Research Division, Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials, Daejeon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Y., Energy Plant Research Division, Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials, Daejeon, South Korea; Ko, J., Energy Plant Research Division, Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials, Daejeon, South Korea; Hong, Y.-J., Energy Plant Research Division, Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials, Daejeon, South Korea; Lee, K.H., Energy Plant Research Division, Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials, Daejeon, South Korea
Abstract: Hydrogen is currently drawing attention as a clean fuel producing less carbon dioxide. The transport and storage, however, require more energy and rather complex infrastructure than fossil fuels. Hydrogen may be stored as liquid, compressed gas, or hydrides. Liquid hydrogen has relatively small density of 50-70 kg/m3, i.e., the volume of hydrogen shrinks less than other gas when it is transformed to a liquid. Moreover, it has low boiling point, and its spin conversion during liquefaction consumes a significant amount of energy. 20-30% of its energy content is required for transport and storage of hydrogen in the liquid state, while compression of hydrogen gas requires 15%. Although such features of hydrogen makes it more complicated to be liquefied, compression of hydrogen gas to 350~700 bar also has technological barriers to be realized. Compression and high pressure storage require larger facilities and heavier storage vessels. It also involves safety concerns, and the compression technology has not yet been matured enough. In this regard, the most economic state of hydrogen for transport and storage is likely to be liquid although the decision may vary according to technological developments. A precooled Claude cycle and a He refrigerated cycle are investigated to develop a pilot scale hydrogen liquefaction system. The simulation results provide the specifications for component development, as well as the advantages of each type of liquefaction cycles.

Authors: Kim D.H., Mudiyanselage K., Szanyi J., Kwak J.H., Peden C.H.F.
Title: Nitrate formation/decomposition on Ba-, and K-based model LNT catalysts: Similarities and differences
Affiliations: Institute for Interfacial Catalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; PNNL, Richland, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, D.H., Institute for Interfacial Catalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Mudiyanselage, K., PNNL, Richland, WA, United States; Szanyi, J., PNNL, Richland, WA, United States; Kwak, J.H., Institute for Interfacial Catalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Peden, C.H.F., Institute for Interfacial Catalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Abstract: Diesel engines are a promising near-term solution for obtaining high energy efficiency because of their unparalleled power density and low CO 2 emissions. However, there are challenges for the catalytic aftertreatment systems, especially due to the necessity to selectively reduce nitrogen oxides (NO x) in the net oxidizing environment. NO x storage-reduction (NSR) catalysts are generally considered as one of the potential options for removing NO x in the diesel engine exhaust. In the NSR technology, alkali or alkaline earth elements (K or Ba) take up NO x under lean operation and store them as nitrates, which are subsequently reduced during rich operation. In this presentation, we compare the characteristics of Ba and K storage elements during NOx adsorption and desorption processes using multiple techniques, including TR-XRD, FTIR and NO 2 TPD. We find that, although both elements store NOx as nitrates, there are significant differences between the morphology changes of the Ba and K nitrates.

Authors: Xu J., Chalmers J.J., Postier B.
Title: Magnetic separation of algal for biofuel production
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, United States; Department of Phycal, St. Louis, MO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Xu, J., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, United States; Chalmers, J.J., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, United States; Postier, B., Department of Phycal, St. Louis, MO, United States
Abstract: Phycal is an algal biofuels company focusing on a hybrid photoautotrophic/heterotrophic open pond system using freshwater algal species. To potentially reduce costs associated with algal biofuels production and/or improve the quality of intermediate steps through improved efficiencies downstream, Phycal is developing strains that can transport and store significantly more iron than wild-type strains. The potential reward is that they can out-compete contaminating species (e.g., algae, bacteria, protozoa, and etc.) for the available iron. Once stored, the iron is in the form of magnetite inside ferritin complexes that are paramagnetic. Thus, in addition to the advantage of iron scavenging, these strains can be manipulated magnetically with the potential of magnetic separation. In this presentation we will present progress on our work to not only over-express genes involved in iron reduction (Fre1), iron transport (Fea1), and iron storage (Fer1), but also our characterization of both the amount of iron within the cells through the use of mass spectrometry and cell tracking velocimetry, CTV. CTV, measures the magnetophoretic mobility, on a cell by cell basis, by measuring the induced velocity of a cell in a well defined magnetic energy gradient. With this measured magnetophoretic mobility, the magnetic susceptibility of the contained iron can be determined, and the potential of high throughput magnetic cell separation technology to separate the magnetic algae predicted.

Authors: Guo J.
Title: Soft X-ray spectroscopy for in situ electronic structure study of nanostructured materials in catalytic reactions
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Advanced Light Source Department, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Guo, J., Advanced Light Source Department, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, CA, United States
Abstract: Solar energy can be converted to electricity and chemical fuels for energy use and storage. Soft x-ray spectroscopy is an element-specific method that is unique for probing electronic and geometric structures of an element of interest within a complex environment. Controlling the crystallographic structure and the arrangement of atoms along the surface of nanostructured material will determine most of its physical and chemical properties. Transition metal (TM) L-edge soft x-ray spectroscopy has been rarely applied to dilute, wet samples and/or biological nanostructured materials. RIXS in combination with XAS, has demonstrated the metal-to-ligand charge transfer occurring between the TM nanoparticle catalyst and surfactant ligands on its surface. The results reveal the electronic structure of the 3d metal compounds in pure form and their variations upon doping. Also, in-situ characterization of metal nanocrystal suspensions demonstrated the way for real-time studies of nanomaterial growth and chemical reactions.

Authors: Calvet N.J., Py X., Olivès R., Bessada C., Echegut P.
Title: Recycling of industrial waste as applied to thermal energy storage
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: CNRS, PROMES Laboratory, Perpignan, France; CNRS, CEMHTI Laboratory, Orléans, France; Energy Cooperative Research Center, CIC ENERGIGUNE, Miñano, Álava, Spain; DOE, NREL, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Calvet, N.J., CNRS, PROMES Laboratory, Perpignan, France, CNRS, CEMHTI Laboratory, Orléans, France, Energy Cooperative Research Center, CIC ENERGIGUNE, Miñano, Álava, Spain, DOE, NREL, Golden, CO, United States; Py, X., CNRS, PROMES Laboratory, Perpignan, France, CNRS, CEMHTI Laboratory, Orléans, France, Energy Cooperative Research Center, CIC ENERGIGUNE, Miñano, Álava, Spain, DOE, NREL, Golden, CO, United States; Olivès, R., CNRS, PROMES Laboratory, Perpignan, France, CNRS, CEMHTI Laboratory, Orléans, France, Energy Cooperative Research Center, CIC ENERGIGUNE, Miñano, Álava, Spain, DOE, NREL, Golden, CO, United States; Bessada, C., CNRS, PROMES Laboratory, Perpignan, France, CNRS, CEMHTI Laboratory, Orléans, France, Energy Cooperative Research Center, CIC ENERGIGUNE, Miñano, Álava, Spain, DOE, NREL, Golden, CO, United States; Echegut, P., CNRS, PROMES Laboratory, Perpignan, France, CNRS, CEMHTI Laboratory, Orléans, France, Energy Cooperative Research Center, CIC ENERGIGUNE, Miñano, Álava, Spain, DOE, NREL, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: The PROMES-CNRS laboratory located in south of France proposed a new sustainable approach for Thermal Energy Storage materials to be used in Concentrated Solar Power Plants: the use of industrial waste treated at high temperature for sustainable energy storage. During the 20 th century 174 million tons of asbestos were used worldwide, principally for building insulation. In 1993 essentially all countries in the world forbid the use of asbestos because of its health hazards. These Asbestos Containing Wastes can be treated at high temperature (1400°C) by plasma torch to produce a totally inert ceramic called COFALIT®, commercially. This first good candidate is available in huge quantity, is very inexpensive (11 dollars/ton) and stable up to 1000°C. This paper presents the thermo-physical characterization of this material and the comparison with other available materials as molten salts, castable ceramics and high temperature concrete.

Authors: Gennett T., Ban C., Braunecker W., Ginley D.S.
Title: Novel organic radical battery matrix
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gennett, T., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Ban, C., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Braunecker, W., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Ginley, D.S., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: The organic radical battery (ORB) is a relatively new class of rechargeable battery (2001) that is based on the utilization of stable organic radical polymer materials that can undergo a reversible oxidation reaction. Due to the reversibility and fast kinetics of the radical self-exchange reaction, the organic radical battery has proven to exhibit the rapid charging capability and excellent cycle life as compared to traditional lithium ion battery electrodes. However in order for the ORBs to go beyond the niche applications, their inherent charge capacity and charge transfer limitations must be better understood and developed. Through a collaborative-interactive effort between electroanalytical, theoretical, synthetic organic and materials chemists, we systematically explore smart designed and synthetically realizable organic radical polymers applicable to batteries. The unique nature of the project is that these disruptive energy storage materials are focused on the utilization of first not only lithium (Li +) but also ammonium (NH 4 +) and/or magnesium ion (Mg +2) based electrolytes for energy storage.

Authors: Grim R.G., Kerkar P.B., Braniff M.J., Sloan E.D., Koh C.A., Sum A.K.
Title: Stability, tuning, and templating of sH hydrogen hydrates for energy storage applications
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grim, R.G., Department of Chemical Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States; Kerkar, P.B., Department of Chemical Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States; Braniff, M.J., Department of Chemical Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States; Sloan, E.D., Department of Chemical Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States; Koh, C.A., Department of Chemical Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States; Sum, A.K., Department of Chemical Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen storage capacity of clathrate structures could be tailored due to their variable sized cages which in some cases can host multiple hydrogen (H 2) molecules. Multiple occupancy in the large 51264 cage of sII hydrates has sparked interest in investigating similar phenomena for other clathrate structures for higher H 2 storage capacity. sH clathrates provide an unique case to study H 2 cage interactions and dynamics due to its three types of cavities in a hexagonal unit cell. The effect of promoter molecule concentration, geometry, diameter, as well as pressure, temperature and various synthesis pathways such as solid-solid mixing of ice and promoter, pressure templating, ice templating, and temperature oscillations were studied on sH large cage (51268) H 2 occupancy using cryogenic Raman spectroscopy. Large cage H 2 stability and the resultant wt% from experiments at pT conditions outside pure H 2 clathrate (sII) stability region while maintaining ice integrity will be presented.

Authors: Nishide H., Suga T.
Title: Redox-active radical polymers for organic-based energy-storage devices
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Applied Chemistry, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nishide, H., Department of Applied Chemistry, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; Suga, T., Department of Applied Chemistry, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Emerging technologies with plastic-based flexible electronic devices have evoked keen interest in exploring next-generation flexible and printable power sources. We focused on durable, but highly redox-active property of organic radical molecules, and have developed a new class of redox polymers for electrode-active, charge-storage materials in a rechargeable battery. Radical polymers bearing a high density of unpaired electrons in a pendant, non-conjugated fashion on each repeating unit provided a rapid, reversible, and quantitative redox behavior in an electrode form. Careful selection of radicals (TEMPO, galvinoxyl, and nitronylnitroxide, etc.) produced remarkably reversible p- and n-type redox couples, which lead to the totally organic-based rechargeable batteries. The power-rate performance of these cells was excellent (a few seconds full charging/discharging), and organic polymer-based electrodes also allowed the fabrication of a flexible, paper-like, and transparent rechargeable energy-storage device. Microphase-separated radical-containing block copolymers and electrospun radical fibers toward new electronics applications will be also discussed.

Authors: Bediako D.K., Nocera D.G.
Title: Oxygen evolution mediated by a nickel-borate thin-film electrocatalyst
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bediako, D.K., Department of Chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Nocera, D.G., Department of Chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Abstract: An attractive method of solar energy storage is the photoelectrochemical splitting of water, since it allows direct access to high energy density storage as molecular hydrogen and oxygen. An essential component of the overall system is an oxygen evolution catalyst that can efficiently accommodate the necessary redox demand, and requires low overpotentials for suitable turnover rates. Insights into the mechanism of oxygen evolution mediated by a nickel-based electrocatalyst will be discussed. Controlled anodic electrodeposition of ultrathin (< 10 nm) catalyst films and electrokinetic studies at intermediate pH regimes have given rise to unique mechanistic insights, including a 30 mV/decade Tafel slope and an inverse third order dependence on proton activity. Furthermore, these mechanistic studies at intermediate pH have been successful in deconvoluting the role of proton acceptor, and the conflicting roles of borate as a proton transfer-facilitating base, and an inhibiting adsorbate.

Authors: Wang C., Luo H., Hillesheim P.C., Dai S.
Title: Tailoring ionic liquids for carbon capture
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Chemical Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Department of Chemistry, University of Tennesse, Knoxville, TN, United States; Energy and Transportation Science Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, C., Chemical Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States, Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China, Department of Chemistry, University of Tennesse, Knoxville, TN, United States, Energy and Transportation Science Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, United States; Luo, H., Chemical Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States, Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China, Department of Chemistry, University of Tennesse, Knoxville, TN, United States, Energy and Transportation Science Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, United States; Hillesheim, P.C., Chemical Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States, Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China, Department of Chemistry, University of Tennesse, Knoxville, TN, United States, Energy and Transportation Science Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, United States; Dai, S., Chemical Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States, Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China, Department of Chemistry, University of Tennesse, Knoxville, TN, United States, Energy and Transportation Science Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, United States
Abstract: The emission of carbon dioxide (CO 2) has received worldwide attention because of its possible implications on climate change. Accordingly, the development of novel sorbent materials and new technologies for CO 2 capture and storage is highly sought. The traditional method for CO 2 capture is chemical absorption by aqueous amine solutions. The key advantages associated with this liquid-based method are high reactivity, low cost, and good absorption capacity. However, the use of amines and water has some serious inherent drawbacks, including the loss of solvent, corrosion, and high energy demand for regeneration. A potential alternative method is the capture of CO 2 by ionic liquids, which have many unique properties, such as negligible vapor pressure, a broad range of liquid temperatures, high thermal stability, good CO 2 solubility, and tunable physicochemical characteristics. Here, we summarized our recent work on the use of room-temperature ionic liquids with tailored structural motifs for efficient carbon capture.

Authors: Matranga C.
Title: Technical challenges associated with the deployment of CO 2 capture and conversion materials
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry and Surface Science, National Energy Technology Laboratory, U.S. Dept. of Energy, Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Matranga, C., Department of Chemistry and Surface Science, National Energy Technology Laboratory, U.S. Dept. of Energy, Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Abstract: The management of CO 2 emissions is one of the most significant political and technical challenges associated with fossil fuel usage. Most reliable predictions indicate that fossil resources will remain critical for meeting the world's energy demand until renewable and nuclear sources can balance our portfolio. Many of the technical challenges associated with CO 2 management can be addressed by developing materials for the direct capture of CO 2, as well as its conversion into revenue generating chemicals sold to offset the costs associated with capture, storage, and monitoring technologies. To address these technical issues, a series of structurally dynamic metal organic framework type sorbents were evaluated for CO 2 capture from mixed gas streams in pre- and post-combustion sources. Likewise, a series of unique nanostructured photocatalysts, using visible light for the photo-conversion of CO 2, have been developed. These materials and the technical challenges associated with their industrial deployment will be discussed.

Authors: Liu J.
Title: 3D nanocomposite for energy storage
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, J., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Abstract: Nanocomposite materials with remarkable good electronic and chemical properties are desired in variety of energy-related devices. In this talk we will discuss our recent research to produce carbon-oxide nanocomposites for energy storage. We will focus on three important issues for making these materials: (1) nucleation and growth on ideal and defected surface, (2) modification for the surface chemistry by surfactant and polymers, and (3) self-assembly of two-dimensional and three-dimensional architectures. The potentials of these nanocomposite materials for practical applications will be illustrated with examples from polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells, Li-ion, Li-S and Li-air batteries.

Authors: Hudson M.R., Brown C.M., Queen W.L.
Title: Hydrogen storage properties of copper and silver exchanged zeolite SSZ-13
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States; NIST Center for Neutron Research, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hudson, M.R., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States, NIST Center for Neutron Research, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD, United States; Brown, C.M., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States, NIST Center for Neutron Research, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD, United States; Queen, W.L., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States, NIST Center for Neutron Research, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD, United States
Abstract: Copper and silver cation-exchanged zeolite SSZ-13 present an interesting opportunity to study the mechanism of interaction of adsorbate gases, primarily hydrogen (H 2), with the ion-exchange sites in zeolites as there is only one type of cation site, in contrast to many zeolites. Cation-exchange in zeolites has been shown to result in more H 2 specific binding sites and higher adsorption capacity. Determining the relationship between the H 2-cation interaction and the type of cation is critical to designing new types of H 2 storage materials, including MOFs and porous carbons. The interaction of H 2 with cation-exchanged zeolites can provide critical information on the relative binding strengths to the zeolite host, as well as how the host framework changes as a function of the quantity of gas adsorbed. We present a multifaceted approach to the study of H 2 adsorption in both copper- and silver-exchanged SSZ-13 and for comparison the host framework SSZ-13. Powder neutron diffraction was employed to locate each of the site specific binding sites for H 2 from in situ adsorption allowing for the accurate determination of the location of the adsorbed gas relative to the zeolite framework. Possible cation-migration as a function of adsorbed H 2 is considered relative to that of gas adsorbed in cation-exchanged zeolites X and Y (FAU). Additionally, inelastic neutron scattering spectroscopy was used to probe the relative rotational energies of the adsorbed H 2 as a function of the quantity of gas loaded. Low-pressure gas adsorption measurements reveal an increased H 2 uptake in the cation-exchanged zeolites over that of the host framework without exchange.

Authors: Miller D., Morreale B., Sorescu D., Guthrie G., Cugini A.
Title: Use of computational approaches to accelerate development and effective deployment of carbon capture and storage technologies
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: National Energy Technology Laboratory, Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, D., National Energy Technology Laboratory, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Morreale, B., National Energy Technology Laboratory, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Sorescu, D., National Energy Technology Laboratory, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Guthrie, G., National Energy Technology Laboratory, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Cugini, A., National Energy Technology Laboratory, Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Abstract: The National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) is at the forefront in the research, development, and assessment of Carbon Capture and Sequestration (CCS) technologies. An important aspect of R&D at NETL is the integration of experimental and computational methods throughout the R&D cycle; from laboratory through pilot scale, and demonstration. Computational techniques have the advantage of being able to describe the structure-property-performance relationships of materials and processes at various time- and length-scales, ranging from atomic interactions through unit operations and systems performance to large-scale deployments.

Authors: Bullock R.M., Yang J.Y., Roberts J.A.S., Kilgore U.J., Helm M.L., Smith S.E., Stewart M.P., Dubois D.L.
Title: Nickel(II) electrocatalysts with pendant amines as proton relays for production of hydrogen and oxidation of hydrogen
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bullock, R.M., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Yang, J.Y., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Roberts, J.A.S., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Kilgore, U.J., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Helm, M.L., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Smith, S.E., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Stewart, M.P., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Dubois, D.L., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Abstract: Increased use of carbon-neutral energy sources requires large scale, reliable storage of energy, due to the intermittent nature of solar and wind energy. Catalysts that efficiently interconvert between electrical energy and chemical bonds (fuels) are needed for a sustainable and flexible energy supply that involves minimal production of greenhouse gases. Reactions that involve transfer of multiple protons and electrons are pervasive in energy science, as exemplified by the two-proton, two-electron oxidation of H 2 and the reverse, production of H 2 by reduction of protons. A series of Ni(diphosphine) 2 2+complexes are catalysts for H 2 production, some with turnover frequencies greater than 1000 s -1. Related Ni(diphosphine) 2 2+ complexes are electrocatalysts for oxidation of hydrogen. Pendant amines incorporated into diphosphines function as proton relays, lowering the barrier for proton mobility and assisting in formation or cleavage of the H-H bond.

Authors: Blackburn J.L., Engtrakul C., Hurst K.E., Bult J.B., Lee J., O'Neill K.J., Parilla P.A., Simpson L.J., Gennett T.
Title: In situ spectroscopic identification of hydrogen binding sites on carbon-based hydrogen sorption materials
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blackburn, J.L., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Engtrakul, C., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Hurst, K.E., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Bult, J.B., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Lee, J., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; O'Neill, K.J., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Parilla, P.A., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Simpson, L.J., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Gennett, T., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: New classes of transition metal (TM)-based hydrogen storage materials, namely spillover (weak chemisorption) materials, have been identified in order to try to meet the Department of Energy's (DOE's) volumetric and gravimetric targets for onboard, reversible vehicular hydrogen refueling and storage. It is proposed that enhanced hydrogen storage on TM doped carbons arises due to hydrogen spillover onto the support. The spillover hydrogen (i.e., atomic hydrogen) has often only been inferred from hydrogen adsorption studies. Optical spectroscopies, such as diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), are very useful for detecting adsorbed hydrogen (physisorption) and have the potential confirm the weak chemisorption of hydrogen on sorption-based materials. Recent experimental efforts have focused on the development of well-defined nanostructured TM supported carbon-based materials with improved weak chemisorption kinetics and sorption capacities. Detailed characterization of these hydrogen storage materials by DRIFTS, including the pressure and temperature relationships for the carbon-hydrogen vibrational modes, will be presented.

Authors: Lin S., Johnson R.S., Smith G.K., Xie D., Guo H.
Title: Pathways for methanol steam reforming involving adsorbed formaldehyde and hydroxyl intermediates on Cu(111): Density functional theory studies
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry, Institute of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Nanjing, China; Department of Chemistry and Biological Chemistry, University of New Mexico, Albuqueruqe, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lin, S., Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry, Institute of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Nanjing, China, Department of Chemistry and Biological Chemistry, University of New Mexico, Albuqueruqe, NM, United States; Johnson, R.S., Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry, Institute of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Nanjing, China, Department of Chemistry and Biological Chemistry, University of New Mexico, Albuqueruqe, NM, United States; Smith, G.K., Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry, Institute of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Nanjing, China, Department of Chemistry and Biological Chemistry, University of New Mexico, Albuqueruqe, NM, United States; Xie, D., Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry, Institute of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Nanjing, China, Department of Chemistry and Biological Chemistry, University of New Mexico, Albuqueruqe, NM, United States; Guo, H., Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry, Institute of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Nanjing, China, Department of Chemistry and Biological Chemistry, University of New Mexico, Albuqueruqe, NM, United States
Abstract: Methanol steam reforming (MSR) has gained considerable interest lately as a potential solution to hydrogen storage and distribution problems in mobile fuel cell applications. We present results of a plane-wave density functional theory study in which we explore the possible MSR pathways on the Cu(111) surface. We focus on various intermediary reactions from adsorbed formaldehyde (CH 2O), an intermediate of methanol decomposition, and adsorbed hydroxyl (OH) formed from water decomposition, through to the final products carbon dioxide (CO 2) and adsorbed hydrogen (H). Three possible pathways have been identified and the lowest two paths through the formate (CHOO) intermediate. Adsorption energies and geometries of all intermediates, as well as the characterization of transition states are reported. Additionally, the effect of hydroxyl assisted disproportionation reactions are shown to drastically reduce barriers for RO-H bond cleavage but have little effect on C-H breaking. These results provide vital information for determining the mechanism of MSR on Cu(111).

Authors: Surendranath Y., Nocera D.G.
Title: Oxygen evolution mediated by a cobalt-based thin-film electrocatalyst
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Surendranath, Y., Department of Chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Nocera, D.G., Department of Chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Abstract: The photoelectrochemical splitting of water into hydrogen and oxygen is an attractive method of solar energy storage. A key component of any photoelectrochemical scheme is an efficient catalyst capable of executing the kinetically demanding oxygen evolution half-reactions. In 2008, we reported that electrolysis of phosphate-buffered solutions of Co 2+ leads to the in-situ formation of a highly active water oxidation catalyst as an amorphous thin film on inert anodes. Recently, X-ray absorption and EPR spectroscopies have been leveraged to uncovered key details of the structure and valency of the catalyst resting state. Against this backdrop, mechanistic insights into the pathway for oxygen evolution mediated by this catalyst will be discussed. Utilizing controlled electrodeposition, ultra-thin catalyst films have been prepared and have allowed for detailed characterization of the kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction at neutral pH. These studies reveal a ∼60 mV Tafel slope, inverse first order dependence on proton activity, and zero order dependence on buffer strength. Together the data points to a mechanism involving a one electron, one proton equilibrium step followed by a chemical rate limiting step for O 2 evolution. These findings will be compared to recent studies on Ni based systems to reveal general periodic trends and key design principles.

Authors: Ma Z.
Title: Integration of wind and concentrating solar power with energy storage for baseload renewable power generation
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: NREL, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ma, Z., NREL, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: Economically storing large quantities of solar- and wind-generated electricity is considered important approach for significant grid penetration by renewable power. The combination of renewable power generation and energy storage could overcome the variability of renewable generation alone and create the opportunity for renewable power to provide base load power. The integration of renewable power and storage of excess electricity for peak power usage improves the peak load response, and to coordinate the electricity supply and demand over the grid. Several energy storage technologies include mechanical, chemical, and electrical methods may be in use or under development. Comparison of their efficiencies and economic uses for different scales and applications will help use the right technology for the right purpose. This work studies the possibility of using thermal energy storage to serve solar- and wind-generation for baseload power generation. The study will describe its configurations and operational efficiencies, and introduce application and development needs for large-scale electricity storage. The work also compares different electricity storage methods ranging from batteries, compressed air energy storage, pumped hydro, and thermal energy storage, to discuss their applications and economic impacts on renewable implementation.

Authors: Kurtz J., Ainscough C., Simpson L.
Title: Report of energy storage needs for early fuel cell motive markets
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kurtz, J., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Ainscough, C., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Simpson, L., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: The market adoption of motive fuel cell systems can be accelerated by improving storage system technologies. Effective improvements in hydrogen storage systems will result in extended product run times, increased productivity, decreased installation and operating costs, improved delivery methods, improved volumetric capacity, and facilitation of siting and permitting processes. These improvements can be achieved through focused R&D efforts based upon an in-depth understanding of storage requirements in key early markets. NREL is identifying storage R&D needs for fuel cell systems for these early markets by obtaining information from key stakeholders through workshops, interviews, questionnaires, and networking. We will present on our findings of end user needs for energy storage in material handling, ground support, public transit and other niche motive fuel cell markets. Our analysis includes a summary of performance capabilities of current hydrogen storage technologies and gaps between current capabilities and the end user performance needs. The gap analysis, combined with an understanding of the early fuel cell motive markets, highlights potential improvements in hydrogen storage systems.

Authors: Rosenthal J.
Title: Ditopic molecular platforms for the conversion of carbon dioxide to energy rich species
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Delaware, Newark, DE, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rosenthal, J., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Delaware, Newark, DE, United States
Abstract: Current concerns over greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and climate change highlight the need for renewable energy generation on a global scale. In the future, the sun will have a predominate role in sustainable energy production, however, cost-effective energy storage is needed for solar to be harnessed as society's primary energy source. Chemical fuels are a sustainable solution to energy storage and carbon based fuels provide optimal energy densities based on volume. Accordingly, a major challenge in renewable energy research is the development of catalysts capable of harnessing renewable energy inputs to produce hydrocarbons and/or fuel precursors directly from carbon dioxide. We are constructing new inorganic platforms to elucidate the molecular design principles that enable efficient CO 2 activation at low overpotentials. The ditopic architectures under consideration have been engineered to provide a cleft for efficient CO 2 binding and reduction. Analysis of these systems' ability to promote CO 2 activation will elucidate the primary factors that drive fuel generation and guide the development of systems that promote CO 2 reduction with high selectivity and efficiency.

Authors: Wang J., Glatzmaier G., Blake D., Curtis C.J.
Title: Bi-Sb alloy nanoparticles for efficient thermal energy storage
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Labroatory, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, J., National Renewable Energy Labroatory, Golden, CO, United States; Glatzmaier, G., National Renewable Energy Labroatory, Golden, CO, United States; Blake, D., National Renewable Energy Labroatory, Golden, CO, United States; Curtis, C.J., National Renewable Energy Labroatory, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: Metal alloy nanoparticles possess both size and composition dependent thermal properties and are therefore promising candidates for phase change materials for efficient thermal energy storage in concentrating solar power systems. Bismuth-antimony (Bi-Sb) alloy has the advantages of low materials cost, high miscibility between Bi and Sb, and tunable melting temperatures between 271°C and 631°C, which covers the working range for next generation parabolic trough systems (300°C to 500°C). Here we report the synthesis and characterization of Bi-Sb nanoparticles. A solution based thermal reduction process was developed for the synthesis of Bi-Sb nanoparticles with tunable size and composition. The size and composition dependent thermal properties were examined using electron microscopy and differential scanning calorimetry. A mechanism for formation of Bi-Sb alloy nanoparticles is proposed and can be applied for the synthesis of other Bi based alloy nanoparticles.

Authors: Pool D.H., Dubois D.L.
Title: Modifying electrodes with nickel-based molecular electrocatalysts for hydrogen production
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pool, D.H., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Dubois, D.L., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Abstract: The complex [Ni(P 2 PhN 2 Ph) 2] +2 { P 2 PhN 2 Ph = 1,3,5,7-tetraphenyl-1,5-diaza-3,7-diphosphacyclooctane} catalyzes the electrochemical reduction of protons to form hydrogen useful for energy storage with a reported rate of 720 s -1. While this is a fast catalyst in a homogeneous solution, to be more useful in an integrated system, it would be useful to immobilize the catalyst at the interface between the electrode and bulk solution. A central issue with such modified electrodes is the transport of electrons and protons to the surface-confined catalyst. This work describes efforts in our laboratory to use functionalized versions of [Ni(P 2 PhN 2 Ph) 2] +2 to modify electrode surfaces in ways that maintain catalytic activity and long term stability. Efforts include using covalent attachment, electropolymerization, thin films of ionic liquid, thin films of ionic liquid combined with Nafion, and adsorption. The more successful methods will be discussed.

Authors: Fox E.B., Au M., Colon-Mercado H.
Title: Catalyst development for Li/air batteries
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Materials Science and Technology Department, Savannah River National Laboratory, Aiken, SC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fox, E.B., Materials Science and Technology Department, Savannah River National Laboratory, Aiken, SC, United States; Au, M., Materials Science and Technology Department, Savannah River National Laboratory, Aiken, SC, United States; Colon-Mercado, H., Materials Science and Technology Department, Savannah River National Laboratory, Aiken, SC, United States
Abstract: Lithium/air batteries are considered the ultimate power source among electrochemical energy conversion and storage cells derived from lithium chemistry. With a theoretical open circuit voltage close to 3 V and a theoretical specific energy of 13 kWh/kg, Li/air batteries have recently gained considerable interest for energy storage due to the high charge transfer that occurs during the oxidation-reduction reactions of lithium. These batteries are unique in that the cathode active material (oxygen) is not stored in the battery.

Authors: Gross A.
Title: First-principles modeling of electrochemical electrode-electrolyte interfaces
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Institute of Theoretical Chemistry, Ulm University, Ulm, Baden-Württemberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gross, A., Institute of Theoretical Chemistry, Ulm University, Ulm, Baden-Württemberg, Germany
Abstract: In spite of its technological relevance in the energy conversion and storage, our knowledge about the microscopic structure of electrochemical electrode-electrolyte interfaces and electrical double layers is still rather limited. However, due to the increase in computer power and the development of efficient algorithms, complex structures and processes at interfaces can nowadays be studied from first principles, i.e., without invoking any empirical parameters, mainly based on periodic density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Furthermore, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations have become possible that can be run for a sufficiently long time to perform meaningful statistical averages in order to derive free energies. In this contribution, recent results of periodic DFT calculations with respect to the structure of the electrochemical water/metal interface will be presented which are relevant for our understanding of elementary steps in electrocatalysis as they occur, e.g., in fuel cells.

Authors: Wakefield B., Goudy A., Orefuwa S., Lott L.Q., Alexander D., Kerr A.
Title: Synthesis of new naphthalene linkers for incorporation in hydrogen storing metal organic frameworks
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Delaware State University, Dover, DE, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wakefield, B., Department of Chemistry, Delaware State University, Dover, DE, United States; Goudy, A., Department of Chemistry, Delaware State University, Dover, DE, United States; Orefuwa, S., Department of Chemistry, Delaware State University, Dover, DE, United States; Lott, L.Q., Department of Chemistry, Delaware State University, Dover, DE, United States; Alexander, D., Department of Chemistry, Delaware State University, Dover, DE, United States; Kerr, A., Department of Chemistry, Delaware State University, Dover, DE, United States
Abstract: As the energy needs of society increase, new environmentally friendly fuels must be identified. Hydrogen is an ideal renewable energy source since it is abundant, non-polluting and has high-energy density. The lack of a practical method to store and release the gas is the challenge to the use of hydrogen. A possible solution to this problem is the development of new metal organic frameworks (MOFs). New organic linkers have been synthesized based on the 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid scaffold using a selective halogenation/cross-coupling strategy. These new linkers have been incorporated into novel MOFs and the hydrogen storage capability of new materials has been determined.

Authors: Olsen M.L., Phok S., Ginley D.S., Parilla P.A.
Title: Development of a high-throughput apparatus for measuring thermal conductivity and creating improved energy storage materials
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Olsen, M.L., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Phok, S., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Ginley, D.S., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Parilla, P.A., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: One of the barriers for the widespread inclusion of concentrating solar power (CSP) technologies for electric power generation is the lack of a suitable thermal energy storage (TES) technology to compensate for the intermittency issues of CSP. Inorganic salts can be used as phase-change materials for TES by taking advantage of their large heats of fusion. However, their low thermal conductivities, particularly in the solid state, hinder the efficient transfer of heat into and out of the salts. We are working to improve the thermal conductivity of alkali nitrate and nitrite salts by the addition of high-aspect-ratio, high-thermal-conductivity micro- and nanoparticles. To this end, we are developing an apparatus for rapid high-throughput measurements of the thermal properties of the composite materials. We will report on the validation of the apparatus and present initial results on the effect of the addition of silicon carbide whiskers on the thermal conductivity of an inorganic phase-change salt at room temperature.

Authors: Wang Y.
Title: Chemistry of nanotube electrode networks
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States; University of Maryland Energy Frontier Research Center, College Park, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Y., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States, University of Maryland Energy Frontier Research Center, College Park, MD, United States
Abstract: The remarkable electrical properties of carbon nanotubes allow opportunities to fabricate high performance conducting wires and electrode networks that may vastly improve energy harvesting, transport, and storage. In this talk I will discuss projects in my lab focused on learning electrical transport through nanotube interfaces in thin film structures and how to synthesize new structures that provide simultaneous solubility and conductivity. The results suggest possibility of uniformly dispersing nanotubes in a matrix with efficient electrical percolation. Both are critical issues in the use of these types of materials in nanocomposites, solar cells and electrical energy storage devices such as lithium ion batteries.

Authors: Wang C.-W., Zhang X.C., Chen Y.-H., Sastry A.M.
Title: State of the art in computational multiphysics/multiscale modeling in lithium-ion batteries
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Sakti3 Inc., Ann Arbor, MI, United States
