Authors with affiliations: Wang, C.-W., Sakti3 Inc., Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Zhang, X.C., Sakti3 Inc., Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Chen, Y.-H., Sakti3 Inc., Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Sastry, A.M., Sakti3 Inc., Ann Arbor, MI, United States
Abstract: Optimization of automotive and wireless energy storage systems using Li-ion batteries in emerging market urgently required understanding how they work. Simulation of Li-ion batteries, resolving statistical variation in the agglomerates that comprise active materials, is the stepping-stone toward this goal. Modeling of Li-ion batteries is a challenging problem due to the presence of two special characteristics of the electrochemical system: multiphysics processes and disparate length and time scales. The length scales in Li-ion batteries can range from particles at the micrometer length scale to the whole cell at the millimeter scale. The time scale in batteries spans from seconds to hours, electrochemical reactions occur in seconds, Li-ion diffusion occurs in minutes, and full cell cycling can take hours, depending on the charge/discharge rate. In these multiple scales, battery systems require multiphysics solutions involving transport of ions and electrons, electrochemical reactions at the solid-electrolyte interface, heat transfer, and intercalation induced stress generation. For these physicochemical processes, the corresponding governing equations are coupled with nonlinear electrochemical kinetics. Multiphysics/multiscale modeling of such a complex system is difficult and numerically expensive, however, once perfected, will allow both understanding of the physicochemical processes of battery electrochemistries and the optimization of battery performance. In our work, we utilize a stochastic approach in constructing model materials so that transport and mechanical properties can be studied from microscale to cell scale. We also present results of coupled multiphysics simulations for rational design of cells and materials.

Authors: Irvine J.T.S.
Title: Electrochemical conversion of carbon dioxide and water
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: School of Chemistry, University of St Andrews, St. Andrews, Fife, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Irvine, J.T.S., School of Chemistry, University of St Andrews, St. Andrews, Fife, United Kingdom
Abstract: Synthetic hydrocarbon fuels prepared from water and carbon dioxide are proposed as alternatives to hydrogen as an energy carrier to enable a carbon neutral energy cycle, given their inherent advantages of high H/C ratio and convenience of storage and transportation. Here we demonstrate two novel strategies for this process. Firstly to directly convert CO2/H2O into hydrocarbon electrochemically in a solid oxide ion conducting electrolyzer in a single reaction step in an efficient electrolyzer with configuration of LSM/YSZ/LaSTi cells combining electrolysis and in-situ Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis Secondly, we demonstrate the successful synthesis of methane via direct electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide in a proton conducting solid oxide electrolyzer based on Ba(CeZrYZn)O 3 at a composite Iron/Iron oxide cathode.

Authors: Meyer T.J.
Title: Oxidizing water and reducing CO 2
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, T.J., Department of Chemistry, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, United States
Abstract: Artificial Photosynthesis and Solar Fuels are key elements in any energy future based on solar energy. Large scale use of solar energy will rely on energy storage on a massive scale with excess solar energy during the day used to create solar fuels for energy production at night. Important energy storage reactions are water splitting into hydrogen and oxygen and water based reduction of CO 2 to hydrocarbons or oxygenates. Impressive advances have been made recently in identifying new families of molecular catalysts for water oxidation, both in solution and on the surfaces of oxide electrodes and semiconductors, and for reducing CO 2. Progress has also been made on coupling catalysis of the half reactions with light absorption and catalysis based on Dye Sensitized Photoelectrosynthesis Cells (DSPEC). Key advances have come from detailed analyses of mechanism, synthetic modification of complexes to maximize rates and surface stability, and integration in assembly structures.

Authors: Benvenuto M.A., Schumack M., Siavoshani S.
Title: Marrying battery chemistry and materials science in a course focused on lithium batteries in advanced electric vehicles
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Detroit Mercy, Detroit, MI, United States; Dow Chemical, Auburn Hills, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Benvenuto, M.A., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Detroit Mercy, Detroit, MI, United States, Dow Chemical, Auburn Hills, MI, United States; Schumack, M., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Detroit Mercy, Detroit, MI, United States, Dow Chemical, Auburn Hills, MI, United States; Siavoshani, S., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Detroit Mercy, Detroit, MI, United States, Dow Chemical, Auburn Hills, MI, United States
Abstract: The University of Detroit Mercy's College of Engineering & Science has recently launched and offers a certificate program on advanced electric vehicles, at the masters' level. One course, taught by the authors, is titled, "Energy Storage Systems." The course begins with a broad view of battery-powered vehicular transportation, and focuses towards lithium-based batteries for automobiles. In developing the course, the instructors found existing reference textbooks and other university courses did almost nothing to couple discussions of lithium batteries with a cradle-to-user or cradle-to-grave scenario of the materials for such batteries. One aim of this course is to attempt to remedy that. The marriage of the basic battery chemistry and the materials science is presented here, as is initial student feedback.

Authors: Simpson L., Gennett T., Parilla P., Blackburn J., Engtrakul C., Zhao Y., Hurst K., Bult J., O'Neill K.
Title: Overview of hydrogen sorbents
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Simpson, L., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Gennett, T., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Parilla, P., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Blackburn, J., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Engtrakul, C., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Zhao, Y., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Hurst, K., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Bult, J., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; O'Neill, K., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: NREL led DOE's Hydrogen Sorption Center of Excellence (HSCoE) and is continuing to evaluate sorbents for use in hydrogen storage applications. Of all material solutions being evaluated today, sorbents provide the only on-vehicle refueling option, can easily be integrated into existing pressurized hydrogen storage systems, and can substantially reduce storage system costs while increasing capacities compared to present high-pressure storage systems. NREL will provide a summary of the accomplishments and recommendations from the 5-year HSCoE efforts. This will include details of the different activities and results, as well as discussions of present and future R&D. The goal of these activities is to develop materials that can meet DOE's targets for vehicular fuel cell and other early market applications. Funding for this effort was provided by the US Department of Energy's Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy as part of DOE's Fuel Cell Technology Program under subcontract DE-AC36-99GO10337 to NREL.

Authors: Shao L., Lutkenhaus J.L.
Title: Polyaniline-containing layer-by-layer assembies: Towards organic energy storage
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States; Artie McFerrin Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas a and M University, College Station, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shao, L., Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States, Artie McFerrin Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas a and M University, College Station, TX, United States; Lutkenhaus, J.L., Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States, Artie McFerrin Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas a and M University, College Station, TX, United States
Abstract: As access to rare earths and other valuable transition metals narrows, the importance of identifying their potential replacements becomes a grand challenge. Cobalt is recognized as a material critical to the manufacture of Li-ion battery cathodes, but the supply of cobalt is limited. One potential alternative cathode material is polyaniline, which can be synthesized from domestic feedstock. Polyaniline is potentially an important material for organic energy storage applications because of polyaniline's high conductivity, specific energy, and cyclability. Indeed, the polyaniline-lithium rechargeable battery (3V coin cell) was commercially available in the late 1980's to early 1990's from Bridgestone-Seiko. However, polyaniline's low specific power presents a major challenge to overcome. We propose that polyaniline/V 2O 5 cathodes made using layer-by-layer (LbL) assembly technique can potentially overcome these challenges by carefully controlling (i) molecular structure via chemical synthesis, (ii) electrode topography, and (iii) mixing via LbL assembly.

Authors: Soper J.D.
Title: Redox-active ligands for low-barrier O-O bond formation at later 3d metals
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Soper, J.D., School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States
Abstract: The need for high density solar energy storage is driving efforts to develop new catalysts for water splitting into hydrogen and oxygen. Oxidative assembly of O 2 from H 2O remains a particularly challenging half reaction, and at the molecular level, the chemical requirements for efficient synthesis of an O-O bond are still not well understood. Previous results from our laboratory have shown how the capacity of some redox non-innocent catechol and aminophenol-derived ligands to undergo single-electron redox changes can lower the kinetic barrier to bimetallic O 2 homolysis at oxorhenium(V). By orthogonalizing ligand-centered 1e- and metal-centered 2e- redox, the complexes apparently utilize an enzyme-like mechanism for O 2 activation wherein the multielectron O 2 cleavage reaction occurs via a series of 1e- steps. This talk will present our most recent efforts to translate these design principles to new iron and manganese complexes that are active for the microscopic reverse reaction, O-O bond formation from radical coupling of two M=O fragments. It will further highlight how redox-active ligands may facilitate generation of oxidizing base metal complexes with destabilized oxo ligands that are key intermediates in water oxidation catalysis.

Authors: Vallett P.J., Damrauer N.
Title: Heterolytic halogen-carbon bond scission photoreactions in ruthenium polypyridyl complexes
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Colorado at Boulder, Boulder, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vallett, P.J., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Colorado at Boulder, Boulder, CO, United States; Damrauer, N., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Colorado at Boulder, Boulder, CO, United States
Abstract: Energy wasting charge recombination is an efficiency limiting process in efforts to achieve solar energy storage. Density functional theory is used to explore the thermodynamics of photochemical energy storage reactions in several ruthenium polypyridyl complexes where heterolytic halogen-carbon bond scission occurs after light-induced formation of the triplet metal to ligand charge transfer ( 3MLCT) state, as seen in the following reaction: [Ru II(A) n(L-X)] 2+ + h? → [Ru III(A) n(L-X) -•] 2+* → [Ru III (A) n(L •)] 3+ + X - (L = polypyridine ligand; X = Cl, Br, and I; A = ancillary ligand). A thermochemical cycle is employed to determine structural and electronic factors influencing ΔErxn. Significant energetic gains in ΔE rxn is achieved through exploiting strain in the coordination geometry and modification of the coulombic forces present. Synthetic targets have been synthesized and evaluated for use in the reaction above via ultafast spectroscopic techniques.

Authors: Yang J., Smith S.E., O'Hagan M., Kilgore U.J., Dubois M.R., Bullock R.M., Dubois D.L.
Title: Molecular nickel diphosphine electrocatalysts for hydrogen oxidation and production: The function of proton relays in the secondary coordination sphere
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yang, J., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Smith, S.E., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; O'Hagan, M., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Kilgore, U.J., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Dubois, M.R., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Bullock, R.M., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Dubois, D.L., Center for Molecular Electrocatalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Abstract: An important prerequisite for the widespread use of energy from renewable sources is the ability to store and recover the energy on demand. The high energy density of chemical bonds makes chemical fuels, such as hydrogen, ideal for energy storage. To this end, efficient and economical catalysts are required for fuel production and oxidation. Hydrogen oxidation and production are multi-electron and multi-proton transformations. The incorporation of proton relays in the secondary coordination sphere of nickel diphosphine complexes is essential to enhancing catalytic rates and improving catalyst efficiency. Mechanistic and theoretical studies on the function of the relays and their role in the catalytic cycles will be presented.

Authors: Kirk M.F., Altman S.J.
Title: Variation in energy available to populations of subsurface anaerobes due to geological carbon storage
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Geochemistry, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirk, M.F., Department of Geochemistry, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Altman, S.J., Department of Geochemistry, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Abstract: We examined variation in energy available to iron and sulfate reducers and methanogens due to changes in groundwater composition during the Frio and ZERT CO 2-injection experiments. Energy available for iron reduction increased significantly during both experiments. Energy for sulfate reducers and methanogens varied little. These changes favor an increased rate of microbial iron reduction following CO 2 injection where iron oxides/oxyhydroxides are available and the rate prior to injection is limited by energy available. This material is based upon work supported as part of the Center for Frontiers of Subsurface Energy Security, an Energy Frontier Research Center funded by the U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Science, Office of Basic Energy Sciences under Award Number DE-SC0001114. Sandia National Laboratories is a multi-program laboratory managed and operated by Sandia Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Lockheed Martin Corporation, for the U.S. Department of Energy's National Nuclear Security Administration under contract DE-AC04-94AL85000.

Authors: Ganesh P., Kent P., Jiang D.-E.
Title: Properties of liquid electrolytes for Li-ion battery applications from first principles molecular dynamics simulation
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Center for Nanophase Materials Sciences, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Division of Chemical Sciences, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ganesh, P., Center for Nanophase Materials Sciences, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States, Division of Chemical Sciences, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Kent, P., Center for Nanophase Materials Sciences, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States, Division of Chemical Sciences, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Jiang, D.-E., Center for Nanophase Materials Sciences, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States, Division of Chemical Sciences, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States
Abstract: A judicious choice of the liquid electrolytes used in battery systems is required to achieve a good balance between high energy storage, fast charging and long lifetime. Ethylene-carbonate (EC), propylene-carbonate (PC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) are popular electrolytes used for this purpose. To date, molecular-dynamics simulations typically rely on classical force-fields, which do not capture the true quantum-mechanical nature of the electrons, most important for the charging/discharging dynamics. We perform accurate first principles molecular-dynamics simulations of EC, PC and DMC with LiPF6 at experimental concentrations to build solvation models which explain available Neutron and NMR results as well as to compute Li-ion solvation energies and diffusion constants. Our results throw light on why EC is a more popular choice for battery applications over PC. Results from simulations of the initial stages in the formation of solid-electrolyte interphases (SEI) in the presence of pre-lithiated carbon electrodes in conventional Li-ion batteries will also be discussed, and perspectives into the likely future scope of these simulations presented. Supported by the Fluid Interface Reactions, Structures and Transport (FIRST) Center, an Energy Frontier Research Center funded by the U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Basic Energy Sciences under Award Number ERKCC61.

Authors: Ganesan V., Sjöholm K.H., Arechederra R.L., Minteer S.D.
Title: Thylakoid-based photobioelectochemical cell for solar energy conversion
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, St. Louis University, St. Louis, MO, United States; Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, UP, India
Authors with affiliations: Ganesan, V., Department of Chemistry, St. Louis University, St. Louis, MO, United States, Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, UP, India; Sjöholm, K.H., Department of Chemistry, St. Louis University, St. Louis, MO, United States, Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, UP, India; Arechederra, R.L., Department of Chemistry, St. Louis University, St. Louis, MO, United States, Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, UP, India; Minteer, S.D., Department of Chemistry, St. Louis University, St. Louis, MO, United States, Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, UP, India
Abstract: Photochemical reactions which can convert light energy into chemical energy have attracted great interest with a view to create new energy conversion and storage systems. The main aim of this work is to develop a biological solar cell based on the intact thylakoid membranes. Thylakoids were isolated from spinach and immobilized on Toray carbon paper with and without indium tin oxide nanopowder (ITONP) using Nafion as an immobilization membrane. They were intact and viable after immobilization on the carbon electrodes. Electrochemical characterization of the thylakoid modified electrode was studied in pH 6.5 phosphate buffer solution. Upon illumination of visible light, the modified electrode produced photocurrent. In the presence of co-immobilized ITONP, photocurrent was increased due to the improved electron transfer process by the increased communication between the electrode and thylakoid membrane. The characterization, electrochemical properties, and the electron transfer mechanism of this photobioelectrochemical cell will be discussed in the paper.

Authors: Yoder T.S., Cloud J.E., Yang Y.
Title: Synthesis and characterization of iron oxyfluoride nanostructures for lithium ion batteries
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yoder, T.S., Department of Chemistry, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States; Cloud, J.E., Department of Chemistry, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States; Yang, Y., Department of Chemistry, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: One important energy storage device is the lithium ion battery (LIB). However, the currently prevailing LIBs are not suitable for large-scale applications due to their poor charge capacity and energy density. One class of potential cathode materials that promises high-performance is metal oxyfluorides. These materials follow the conversion mechanism for lithium storage that has been discovered with metal oxides and metal fluorides; these materials can accommodate a charge capacity 2-3 times that of traditional cathode materials via an intercalation mechanism. We will report a low-temperature hydrothermal process for synthesizing FeOF nanostructures. First, FeOOH nanostructures will be made by electrodeposition (Fe 2+ + 3OH - → FeOOH + H 2O + e -). The second step is to convert FeOOH into FeOF (FeOOH + NH 4F → FeOF + NH 3- + H 2O) using ammonium fluoride as the fluorinating agent. The intermediate and final products are characterized by XRD, SEM, EDX, and TEM.

Authors: Pradhan S., Curtis C.J., Blake D., Glatzmaier G.
Title: Technologically relevant nanomaterials for thermal energy storage in concentrated solar power plants
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Chemical and Materials Science Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Concentrated Solar Power Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pradhan, S., Chemical and Materials Science Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States, Concentrated Solar Power Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Curtis, C.J., Chemical and Materials Science Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States, Concentrated Solar Power Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Blake, D., Chemical and Materials Science Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States, Concentrated Solar Power Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Glatzmaier, G., Chemical and Materials Science Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States, Concentrated Solar Power Center, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States
Abstract: The goal of this investigation is to identify new materials based on nanotechnology which can significantly increase the thermal energy storage densities over the current state of the art. The advantage of using nanomaterials is that they posses thermal properties dependent on the number of atoms in the particle because of which phase change can occur over a broad range of temperature, depending on the particle size, rather than at a discrete temperature as is characteristic of bulk materials. We employed silica capped silver nanoparticles as our test particle which clearly demonstrated size dependent melting properties as observed in temperature dependent transmission electron microscopy. The studies were further extrapolated to mesoporous materials namely mobile crystalline material (MCM) where particles and nitrate salts were impregnated into the pores of MCM at various loading capacities followed by calorimetric measurements. Promising initial results indicate that these materials are strong candidates for thermal energy storage.

Authors: Wiemhoefer H.-D.
Title: Materials for electrochemical energy storage in high energy density batteries
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: University of Muenster, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wiemhoefer, H.-D., University of Muenster, Germany
Abstract: Research on functional materials with electron and/or ion conductivity plays a decisive role on the way towards high efficiency in chemical energy storage, energy conversion and many chemical process technologies. The focus of our R&D lies on developing and testing new and modified electrolyte and electrode materials for electrochemical devices, e.g. batteries with improved stability and enhanced performance and energy density. Producing and testing battery cells is an integral part of this activity. A particular emphasis of our accompanying fundamental research lies on the investigation and control of the micro and nano-electrochemistry, e.g. the stability of electrolyte/electrode systems and the fast exchange of ions and electrons at the nano-particle interfaces of active electrodes. Recent results from current projects will be reported on new and improved stable electrolytes and electrolyte/electrode systems. These are an important pre-condition on the route to high energy density lithium batteries. Emphasis lies on polymer based hybrid electrolytes as well as on polymer concepts for nanostructured electrodes. Chemically modified polymer and copolymer networks, for instance polysiloxanes, polyphosphazenes and others offer an excellent starting point together with suitable additives and modifiers towards high performance electrolytes and electrodes.

Authors: Abbott L.J., Hart K.E., Larsen G.S., Lin P., Colina C.M.
Title: Novel nanoporous polymers: In silico design
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States; Materials Simulation Center, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abbott, L.J., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States, Materials Simulation Center, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States; Hart, K.E., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States, Materials Simulation Center, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States; Larsen, G.S., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States, Materials Simulation Center, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States; Lin, P., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States, Materials Simulation Center, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States; Colina, C.M., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States, Materials Simulation Center, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, United States
Abstract: Organic microporous materials offer a new approach to environmentally conscious and energy efficient gas storage and separation technology, such as O 2/N 2 separation, methane purification, and CO 2 capture. We are using molecular simulations to study novel nanoporous compounds such as hypercrosslinked polymer and polymers of intrinsic microporosity. Our approach focuses on developing an atomistic understanding of the porous structures of these materials, as well as the interactions between gases and a sorbent matrix. Here, our recently developed procedure for generating complex structure of amorphous polymers is described, and applied to a wide range of polymeric systems including both linear and networked. A suite of characterization techniques to determine key physical properties such as x-ray scattering patterns, surface areas, and pore size distributions for comparison with experimental data is also described. Finally, how in silico design can created novel structures, screen new materials and help provide directions for experimental work is addressed.

Authors: Lin Y., Daga V.K., Anderson E.A., Gido S.P., Watkins J.J.
Title: High volume production of well-ordered hybrid materials for device applications
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lin, Y., Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States; Daga, V.K., Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States; Anderson, E.A., Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States; Gido, S.P., Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States; Watkins, J.J., Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States
Abstract: The preparation of well ordered, hybrid polymer/inorganic nanostructures with exceptional control over size, shape, composition and organization of the nanoscale domains is central to the development of next-generation materials and devices for energy generation and storage, microelectronics, communications, photonics and other applications. While the desired structures can often be identified, their realization via practical fabrication methods has remained challenging, especially for those cases that require high concentrations of nanoparticles (NPs) or other functional additives within ordered periodic structures. Here we report that nanostructured templates with periodic spherical, cylindrical, and lamellar morphologies exhibiting sub-10 nm domains can be easily obtained through the blending of commercially available disordered polymer surfactants with commodity homopolymers that selectively associate with one segment of the surfactant. We further demonstrate that order in the surfactant systems and in block copolymer templates can be induced by nanoparticle additives that undergo multi-point hydrogen bonding with one of the segments of the polymer template. These additives, which include metal and semiconducting nanoparticles, fullerenes, and other active components, impart functionality to the device. The strong interactions further enable particle loadings of more than 40% in the target phase, resolving a crucial constraint for many applications. The behavior of the template and composite systems, their fabrication using conventional printing and coating technologies, and their use in well ordered hybrid materials for flexible photovoltaic devices and other applications will be discussed.

Authors: Sharma K.R.
Title: On PW analysis on hydrogen production from fast pyrolysis and steam reforming
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Prairie View a and M University, Prairie View, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, K.R., Department of Chemical Engineering, Prairie View a and M University, Prairie View, TX, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen is considered as an alternative fuel in the transportation sector. In one process the biomass is pyrolyzed and then steam reformed to yield hydrogen. Biomass is dried and then converted to oil by very quick exposure to heated particles in a fluidized bed. The char and gases produced are combusted to supply heat to the reactor. The product oils are cooled and condensed. Bio-oil is then shipped by truck from the plant location(s) to the hydrogen production facility. By shipping the bio-oil which has a higher energy density rather than the biomass transportation costs are reduced. On arrival the bio-oil is fractionated using water extraction into carbohydrate fraction and lignin fractions. The carbohydrate fraction is steam reformed and the hydrogen that is formed is separated using PSA, pressure swing adsorption. Consider a plant that produces 75,790 kg/day of hydrogen by the pyrolysis process. The biomass feed rate is about 1806 Mg/day. Capital investment fixed costs are $59.4 million. The selling price of hydrogen is $10/GJ. The storage and transportation cost of hydrogen through railroad is $0.94/GJ. The calorific value of hydrogen is 142 MJ/kg. At a MARR of 11% the PW of the project was calcualted. The plant has operated for 5 years. The biomass feedstock cost was $16.5/Mg. The plant operated at 80% time during the year. The cost of utility and wages of laborers can be lumped into 15c/kg of hydrogen produced.

Authors: Bates D.J., Johnson D.C., Mosby J.M., Rawls M.T., Prieto A.L.
Title: Electrodeposition as a synthetic tool for solid-state energy storage materials
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, United States; Research and Development, Prieto Battery, Inc., Fort Collins, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bates, D.J., Department of Chemistry, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, United States, Research and Development, Prieto Battery, Inc., Fort Collins, CO, United States; Johnson, D.C., Department of Chemistry, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, United States, Research and Development, Prieto Battery, Inc., Fort Collins, CO, United States; Mosby, J.M., Department of Chemistry, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, United States, Research and Development, Prieto Battery, Inc., Fort Collins, CO, United States; Rawls, M.T., Department of Chemistry, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, United States, Research and Development, Prieto Battery, Inc., Fort Collins, CO, United States; Prieto, A.L., Department of Chemistry, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, United States, Research and Development, Prieto Battery, Inc., Fort Collins, CO, United States
Abstract: We are using electrodeposition as the main synthetic tool for the fabrication of a three-dimensional (3D) lithium-ion rechargeable battery. The proposed battery architecture offers the possibility of higher power density and longer cycle life. The direct electrodeposition of crystalline copper antimonide is key to this battery architecture, and provides a high surface area anode that is electrically conductive without the need for additional binders. The 'mechanism' for the electrodeposition of this interesting intermetallic will be discussed. Then, two architectures, one based on a nanowire array and one based on high surface area foams will be presented. Cycling data will be shown demonstrating that the nanostructured copper antimonide shows significantly enhanced capacity retention over the bulk material after many cycles. Finally, the electrodeposition of ultra thin, conformal coatings of separator materials directly onto the copper antimonide anode electrode will be illustrated. Battery performance of these composite structures will also be presented.

Authors: Pratt III H.D., Ingersoll D., Alam T.M., Rose A.J., Anderson T.M.
Title: Synthesis and characterization of polyoxometalates for energy storage applications
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Advanced Power Sources, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pratt III, H.D., Advanced Power Sources, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Ingersoll, D., Advanced Power Sources, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Alam, T.M., Advanced Power Sources, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Rose, A.J., Advanced Power Sources, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Anderson, T.M., Advanced Power Sources, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Abstract: Energy consumption is projected to increase at least two-fold by mid-century. In order to further incorporate intermittent renewable energy sources to help meet this need, advancements must be made in large-scale energy storage. Concentrating on promising flow battery technologies, we have synthesized a series of metal-oxide clusters, collectively known as polyoxometalates, to determine their ability to store charge. After identifying reversible redox pairs by cyclic voltammetry, we performed bulk electrolysis to reduce the fully oxidized materials, and demonstrated by NMR, they are stable to multi-electron reductions. Impedance measurements indicate high specific conductivity in both aqueous and non-aqueous solvents. In addition, we have examined the structural and compositional effects on the fundamental electrochemical properties of the materials. Emphasis has been placed on polyoxometalates in non-aqueous solvents due to their higher stability and wider voltage window.

Authors: Rosso K.M., Sushko M.L., Sushko P.V., Hu S., Li Y.
Title: Multi-scale computational approaches to coupled polaronic and ion transport in nanocrystalline metal oxide electrodes
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Geochemistry Department, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; London Centre for Nanotechnology, University College London, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Rosso, K.M., Geochemistry Department, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States, London Centre for Nanotechnology, University College London, London, United Kingdom; Sushko, M.L., Geochemistry Department, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States, London Centre for Nanotechnology, University College London, London, United Kingdom; Sushko, P.V., Geochemistry Department, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States, London Centre for Nanotechnology, University College London, London, United Kingdom; Hu, S., Geochemistry Department, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States, London Centre for Nanotechnology, University College London, London, United Kingdom; Li, Y., Geochemistry Department, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States, London Centre for Nanotechnology, University College London, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: We report new theoretical approaches and fundamental understanding in the dynamics of coupled charge and ion transport in nanoscale metal oxides. The modeling effort attacks the multi-scale problem of simulating the collective diffusivities of ions and charge compensating e-/h+ carriers in single crystal particles, across particle-particle grain boundaries, and through networks of grains for select systems. We are presently focused on coupled electron and Li + ion transport in polymorphs of TiO 2, a problem of relevance to energy storage materials optimization for Li + batteries. Methods include embedded QM/MM clusters at the DFT level for atomic-scale polaronic and ion transport kinetics, classical DFT-based free energy calculations for grain-scale conductivity in the framework of the Poisson-Nernst-Planck formalism, and phase field simulation of charged particle diffusivity for conductivity at the grain network scale. This combination of approaches is one of a kind in terms of its multi-scale range, scaling, and computational efficiency.

Authors: Murph S.H.
Title: Advanced nanocomposite materials with energy related applications
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Savannah River National Laboratory, Aiken, SC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murph, S.H., Savannah River National Laboratory, Aiken, SC, United States
Abstract: Energy is the vital force powering every aspect of our society from business, manufacturing, transportation of products, and services to serve the people and worlds economies. Nanotechnology has introduced new concepts for innovative technology applications in energy research, such as solar energy harvesting, storage and conversion, hydrogen production and storage, conversion and use of energy (fuel cells) etc. optical and chemical sensors, photonics, imaging, and drug delivery systems. In this presentation we bring to light recent advances in our laboratory on synthesis, characterization, optical and physico-chemical properties of colloidal materials with energy production applications; particularly, we highlights work from the authors' laboratories in catalytic applications in fuel cells processes and solar cells applications, using noble metallic nanoparticles including gold, silver and platinum and oxide nanoparticles (e.g. silica, titania, MnOx). We'll focus on isotropic and anisotropic nano-composite materials, solid and hollow nanomaterials, core-shell and alloy type nanomaterials, monometallic and bimetallic nanoparticles with applications for solar and fuell cells.

Authors: Verbrugge M.W.
Title: The emergence of electrified vehicles
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Materials and Processes Lab., General Motors R and D Lab., Warren, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Verbrugge, M.W., Materials and Processes Lab., General Motors R and D Lab., Warren, MI, United States
Abstract: The first portion of the lecture will relate global energy challenges, trends in personal transportation, and electrochemical energy storage technologies. Great progress has been made in recent years relative to battery technology, as exemplified by the Chevy Volt coming to market. Primary concerns associated with lithium ion batteries and high-volume traction applications are associated with cost, life (cycle and calendar), and performance over a wide temperature range. Despite these concerns, it is well recognized that soon lithium ion batteries will be used in a variety of electrified vehicles, spanning from engine start/stop applications to hybrid electric vehicles to pure electric vehicles. Hence, it is critically important to understand phenomena governing the durability of lithium ion cells within the context of traction applications. We focus the technical part of this talk on the combined mechanical and chemical degradation of lithium ion electrode materials, including both recent theoretical and experimental methods to clarify the governing phenomena.

Authors: Meyer T.J.
Title: Following the electrons to solar fuels
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, T.J., Department of Chemistry, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, United States
Abstract: Because of its intermittency, the sun goes down at night, solar energy cannot be the primary energy source in a new energy future without energy storage on a massive scale. The only reasonable approach is chemistry and using the sun to drive water splitting or water reduction of CO 2 to hydrocarbons or oxygenates. Coupling light absorption with catalysis to drive such difficult multiple electron half reactions- 2 H 2O à O 2 + 4 H +; CO 2 + 8 e - + 8 H + à CH 4 + 2 H 2O- is intimidating. A strategy evolved in the early 1970s based on electron transfer of quenching of metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) excited states of Ru(bpy) 3 2+ and related complexes. Subsequent research, keyed to the solar fuel challenge, has led to new approaches and new insights in water oxidation catalysis, CO 2 reduction catalysis, Proton Coupled Electron Transfer, and excited state properties and reactivity. Advances in chemical synthesis of polypyridyl complexes, molecular assemblies, and surface binding and characterization have provided a basis for assembly and integration. These provide the key elements for solar fuels production in both natural and artificial photosynthesis: light absorption, excited state electron transfer, vectorial electron/energy/proton transfer through free energy gradients, electron transfer activation of catalysis, and rapid catalysis of target half reactions. All of these elements are available in Dye Sensitized Photoelectrosynthesis Cells (DSPEC) driven by excited state electron or hole injection at semiconductor surfaces and a "modular" approach.

Authors: Beliak I., Butenko L.
Title: Development of fluorescent multilayer disc structure
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Istitute for Information Recording (IIR), National Academy of Science of Ukraine (NASU), Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Beliak, I., Istitute for Information Recording (IIR), National Academy of Science of Ukraine (NASU), Ukraine; Butenko, L., Istitute for Information Recording (IIR), National Academy of Science of Ukraine (NASU), Ukraine
Abstract: The fluorescent multilayer disc (FMD) consists of a substrate and the sandwich-structure of information and intermediate layers. While all the structure of the disc is transparent and homogeneous the parasitic signal will be caused mostly by photoluminescence (PL) and absorption of pits areas where laser light is unfocused. At large number of layers (10 or more) the noise level will get significant value, so it was suggested to derive readout signal as a variable one. Also it was proposed to record information only by the lands, to decrease the absorbance level and thus uncontrolled changing of the noise level. Furthermore in the FMD information layer there are inner and outside peripheral areas which hold a stable level of parasitic signal during readout from the edges of the disc. While the PL readout signal is spatially isotropic the optical head of the FMD drive receives just a part of the probing beam energy. PL quantum yield, absorption factor, receiver systems exposure loss coefficients are other reasons of the low PL signal. Thus the problem of the low SNR in this case is a major one and the only way of its solving is synthesis of the dye with a high PL quantum yield. The PL relaxation time on the other hand is a main feature of the data reading rate and therefore selection of the appropriate recording material will allow to bring this parameter in accordance to parameters of modern optical discs. To achieve this goal the composite organic pyrazoline dyes where synthesized and investigated as effective medium with a PL quantum yield up to 60-70%, relaxation time less than 100 ns, PL wide spectrum and opportunity of two-photon absorption. These parameters were further improved by a method based on the performance of organic dye molecules in the zeolite matrix. © 2011 Copyright Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers (SPIE).
Author Keywords: fluorescent multilayer disc; nanostructure; optical recording; pyrazoline dye; recording layer; zeolite
Index Keywords: Absorbances; Absorption factor; Data-reading; Disc structures; Effective medium; fluorescent multilayer disc; Information layers; Intermediate layers; Laser lights; Loss coefficients; Low SNR; Noise levels; Number of layers; Optical discs; Optical heads; Organic dye molecules; Parasitic signals; PL quantum yield; Probing beams; Pyrazolines; Readout signals; Receiver system; Record information; Recording layers; Recording materials; Two-photon absorptions; Wide spectrum; Zeolite matrix; Feature extraction; Fluorescence; Multilayers; Nanostructures; Optical disk storage; Optical recording; Quantum yield; Signal receivers; Two photon processes; Zeolites; Light

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Grid and Cloud Middleware - International Conference on Computing in High Energy and Nuclear Physics, CHEP 2010
Abstract: The proceedings contain 48 papers. The topics discussed include: an update on the scalability limits of the Condor batch system; synchrotron imaging computations on the grid without the computing element; improving security in the ATLAS PanDA system; migration to the GLUE 2.0 information schema in the LCG/EGEE/EGI production grid; tuning grid storage resources for LHC data analysis; adaptive data management in the ARC grid middleware; designing the next generation grid information system; CernVM co-pilot: a framework for orchestrating virtual machines running applications of LHC experiments on the cloud; a batch system for HEP applications on a distributed IaaS cloud; message passing framework for globally interconnected clusters; integration of cloud, grid and local cluster resources with DIRAC; and Adoption of a SAML-XACML profile for authorization interoperability across grid middleware in OSG and EGEE.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Computing Fabrics and Networking Technologies - International Conference on Computing in High Energy and Nuclear Physics, CHEP 2010
Abstract: The proceedings contain 34 papers. The topics discussed include: computing infrastructure for ATLAS data analysis in the Italian grid cloud; Cluman: advanced cluster management for the large-scale infrastructures; autonomous system management for the ALICE high-level-trigger cluster using the SysMES framework; online data storage service strategy for the CERN computer centre; INFN-CNAF tier-1 storage and data management systems for the LHC experiments; the national analysis facility at DESY - status and use cases by the participating experiments; improving CMS data transfers among its distributed computing facilities; powering physics data transfers with FDT; high throughput WAN data transfer with Hadoop-based storage; WNoDeS, a tool for integrated grid and cloud access and computing farm virtualization; first challenges for the ALICE Tier2 centre at GSI; and building a high performance computing infrastructure for novosibirsk scientific center.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Plenary - International Conference on Computing in High Energy and Nuclear Physics, CHEP 2010
Abstract: The proceedings contain 9 papers. The topics discussed include: joining the petabyte club with direct attached storage; the US-CMS Tier1 centre network evolving toward 100Gbps; how to harness the performance potential of current multi-core processors; ATLAS, CMS and new challenges for public communication; StorNet: integrated dynamic storage and network resource provisioning and management for automated data transfers; a new generation of networks and computing models for high energy physics in the LHC era; data preservation in high energy physics; an analysis of bulk data movement patterns in large-scale scientific collaborations; and data-oriented scheduling for PROOF.

Authors: Nayak S., Garcia S., Carreto V., Mannan S.
Title: Can a liquid hydrogen storage tank BLEVE?
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nayak, S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, United States; Garcia, S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, United States; Carreto, V., Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, United States; Mannan, S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, United States
Abstract: A BLEVE (boiling-liquid expanding-vapor explosion) occurs when a tank containing liquefied gas ruptures, resulting in the instantaneous release of the vapor, boiling liquid, missiles (tank fragments), and blast wave 1. The most common type of the BLEVE is caused when the external wall of the tank is exposed to a fire 1. The continuous heat transfer from the fire to the tank wall increases the temperature and pressure inside the tank, until the tank fails. This sudden failure of the tank results in an explosive vaporization of its contents. In passenger cars the LH 2 is stored as a cryogenic liquid at -240 °C and at moderate pressures (20 to 30 bars) 2. It is believed that the LH 2 will not BLEVE, since it is stored at such a low temperature3. However, LNG, which is also stored as a cryogenic liquid presents a potential for BLEVE 4. Consequently, in this study we have theoretically investigated if the LH 2 storage tanks will BLEVE. A theoretical model considering transient mass and energy transfer is developed and solved numerically5. It is assumed that the LH 2 tank is engulfed in a fire and the fire is caused due to spilled gasoline or hydrogen. Different tank materials and insulations are tested. The transient model has a capability to predict the time required for the LH 2 tank to BLEVE. This prediction will be useful for the fire fighters and emergency responders when dealing with LH2 tank engulfed in a fire. Finally the consequences due to the BLEVE of LH 2 tank are also studied.

Authors: Wissinger J., Bosley A.L., Schall C.
Title: Determining the role of algal biopolymers in hydrolysis of triacylglycerides to free fatty acids
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, University of Toledo, Toledo, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wissinger, J., Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, University of Toledo, Toledo, OH, United States; Bosley, A.L., Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, University of Toledo, Toledo, OH, United States; Schall, C., Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, University of Toledo, Toledo, OH, United States
Abstract: Microalgae are a third generation of biofuels and an alternative to woody biomass in production of liquid transportation fuels. The main carbon rich components of algal biomass include protein, carbohydrates, and lipids. The balance of these components within a specific algal species is a affected by the environment in which it is cultivated. Proteins in algae can provide energy storage, structural support, and maintain internal function. Carbohydrates, such as starch, provide energy storage and cell structure. Lipids are involved in structure of the algae cells, energy storage, and are used as signaling molecules. High lipid content in algae used for fuel processing is attractive due to the high yields per acre compared to terrestrial crops. Triacylglycerides (lipids) can be converted to free fatty acids via hydrolysis in subcritical water. Subcritical water is attractive due to the elimination of organic solvents and catalysts, which can be difficult to remove and expensive. This eliminates energy intensive drying steps prior to hydrolysis, allowing for algae, as received, to be processed. High temperature can denature and char protein components. These proteins are a valuable byproduct of algae useful as a livestock feed or food supplement. The effects of polysaccharides and other constituents at subcritical conditions are also of interest to determine the behavior of algal species during hydrolysis. The focus of this research is evaluating the effects of pre-processing algal samples for hydrolysis of triacylglycerides to free fatty acids. Extraction of algal constituents prior to hydrolysis impacts charring at elevated temperatures, conserves profitable by-products, and can ease downstream material handling.

Authors: Shinkle A.A., Sleightholme A.E.S., Thompson L.T., Monroe C.W.
Title: Active species concentration effects on performance for a non-aqueous all-vanadium redox flow battery
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shinkle, A.A., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Sleightholme, A.E.S., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Thompson, L.T., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Monroe, C.W., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States
Abstract: Redox flow batteries(RFBs) are being developed for large-scale energy storage, uninterruptable grid-independent power supplies and load-leveling systems for solar or windpower. Aqueous chemistries are used for all current commercial RFBs, therefore, cell potentials are limited to thestability range of water (01.23 V vs. SHE). Since a battery's cellpotential determines its energy and power density, aqueous chemistries limitthe possibilities for the performance of RFBs. Several non-aqueous systems have beenreported recently, including systems based on ruthenium, uranium, chromium, manganese, and vanadium coordination complexes. In the case ofvanadium acetylacetonate, the use of a non-aqueous electrolyte results in a stablecell potential window of 2.2 V, more than 50% wider than the aqueoussingle-metal vanadium chemistry (1.26 V). However, very few resultsfrom battery charge/discharge experiments have been shown for this non-aqueousvanadium system. This talk will examine thecharge/discharge profile for the vanadium acetylacetonate (V(acac) 3)RFB system in acetonitrile, with tetraethylammonium tetrafluoroborate (TEABF 4)support. The effects of active-species concentration on batteryperformance were examined. Linear sweep voltammetry will be used todetermine the maximum charge/discharge rate of the battery cell as a functionof electrolyte composition. Figure 1 shows the first five cycles of acharge/discharge result for 0.4 M V(acac) 3,0.5 M TEABF 4 in acetonitrile. Coulombic, energy, and powerefficiency for charge/discharge experiments were examined as a function of concentration to illustrate the effects of active species crossover. Efficiency and energy density were balanced to determine an optimal active species concentration range for operation of the battery. Lastly, the non-aqueous system was compared to the optimized aqueous all-vanadium system to identify areas of future work.

Authors: Mayes R.T., Kiggans J.O., Tsouris C., Dai S., DePaoli D.W.
Title: Self-assembled, nanostructured carbon for energy storage and water treatment
Affiliations: Chemical Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Materials Science and Technology Division, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Energy and Transportation Science Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mayes, R.T., Chemical Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Materials Science and Technology Division, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Kiggans, J.O., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Tsouris, C., Energy and Transportation Science Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Dai, S., Chemical Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Materials Science and Technology Division, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; DePaoli, D.W., Energy and Transportation Science Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States
Abstract: This talk will present progress in efforts aimed at translating a unique approach for synthesis of self-assembled nanostructured carbon into industrially viable technologies for two important applications: electrochemical double-layer capacitors for energy storage, and capacitive deionization systems for water treatment. Self-assembly through templating is one way to tailor carbon-based materials, enabling the formation of a uniform porous network in the mesopore size regime via manipulation and control of macroscopic process variables. These tailorable, nanostructured materials are synthesized by self assembly in solution, followed by heat treatment. Further activation results in a bimodal pore structure where micropores are present with the mesopores. The larger mesopores allow for faster electrolyte transport. Characteristics of templated carbons having relatively high surface areas and hierarchical pore structures will be presented, as well as measurements of their specific capacitance under conditions relevant to applications. A focus of the presentation is on recent efforts to convert the mesoporous carbon into electrode materials that may be used practically in capacitive deionization devices. Previous work had indicated that ORNL's mesoporous carbon (OMC) had attractive electrical performance; bench scale testing of the material showed significantly better performance in terms of capacity than commercial aerogel material. However, a previous approach to generate electrodes suffered from variability and mechanical problems. More recent advances have generated materials that utilize the mesoporous carbon in a form more suitable for CDI electrodes in industrial application. Results of prototype testing will be presented.

Authors: Bidstrup-Allen S.A., Armutlulu A., Fang Y., Allen M.G.
Title: Micromachined high surface area structures for energy storage applications
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bidstrup-Allen, S.A., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States; Armutlulu, A., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States; Fang, Y., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States; Allen, M.G., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States
Abstract: A micron-scale, high surface area metallic structure was built based on a sequential multilayer robotic electroplating process. Alternating Ni and Cu layers were electrodeposited from their respective plating baths, followed by selective and partial chemical etching of the Cu layers to obtain a final high surface area Ni structure which was intended to serve as a backbone for the anode electrode in Zn-air microbatteries. The last step of anode fabrication process involves electrodeposition of Zn layer onto the Ni backbone structure. This fabrication resulted in a high surface area electrode with a reduction in internal resistance, which are crucial for high performance batteries, particularly at high discharge rates. Using this approach, an electrode composed of 10 pairs of Ni and Cu layers was built and tested. The surface area of the electrode was found to be more than 6 times higher than that of its footprint. Based on the discharge tests through various electrical loads, the areal capacity and energy density were measured as ∼2.5 mAh/cm 2 and 2.5-3mWh/cm 2, respectively.

Authors: Eitouni H.B.
Title: Structured polymers for energy generation and storage
Affiliations: Seeo, Inc., Hayward, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eitouni, H.B., Seeo, Inc., Hayward, CA, United States
Abstract: Reduction of both greenhouse gas emissions and U.S. dependence on foreign oil will require the widespread adoption of electric vehicles, renewable power generation, and smart electrical grids. The current bottleneck to extensive deployment of both electric vehicles and smart electrical grids is the battery. Adoption by major utility companies of renewable energy plants, such as those based on photovoltaics, is hindered for two reasons. Stabilization of the intermittent power generation requires inexpensive long-life battery systems, which are yet to be developed. Additionally, power derived from photovoltaics is still too expensive to compete with electricity derived from fossil fuels. Deploying these applications will call for entirely new energy generation and storage innovations. In my poster presentation I will highlight examples both from my graduate research and from my accomplishments at Seeo Inc., the start-up company I co-founded. I will discuss how electrochemistry can be used to control assembly of block copolymers and, reciprocally, how structured nanomaterials can be used to control electrochemical device function, particularly in the case of stable high energy batteries. Building on my past work, I will describe my plans to create a research program aimed at obtaining a fundamental understanding of the structure-property-function relationships in nano-structured polymers as they apply to devices for advanced energy generation and storage. During my graduate work, I synthesized and studied organometallic block copolymers, wherein one block was composed of alternating ferrocene and dialkylsilane units in the main chain. Similarly to typical organic block copolymers, they underwent self-assembly to form microphase-separated ordered structures, and I characterized the phase behavior and thermodynamic interactions of the poly(ferrocenyldimethylsilane) system with multiple copolymers. The thermodynamic interactions in poly(ferrocenyldimethylsilane) diblock copolymers were systematically adjusted by oxidizing the ferrocene moieties with silver salts and examined using SAXS and depolarized light scattering. The polymers retained microphase separated ordered structures upon oxidation and showed systematic changes in the location of the order-disorder transition as a function of extent of oxidation. By controlling the redox properties of the ferrocene moiety in the backbone of the polymer, I developed a method for controlling the self-assembled microstructure and hence bulk material properties. Furthermore, using electrochemical techniques, a novel means of controlling the order-disorder transition of block copolymers was discovered. By applying very small electrochemical potentials to disordered solutions of the organometallic block copolymers, oriented ordered grains were formed near one electrode, the result of electrochemical reactions. After reversing the electrical bias on the system, the ordered grains disappeared and new oriented ordered regions were formed at the opposite electrode. Our work established a fundamentally new mechanism for controlling the self-assembly of block copolymers. More recently as Director of Materials Development at Seeo Inc., I have focused on developing commercially viable lithium battery systems based on solid-state polymeric electrolytes. Solid-state batteries have long been a goal of rechargeable battery development. Today's conventional batteries rely exclusively on organic liquid electrolytes, whose volatility and reactivity are responsible for the most significant limitations to battery life and safety. Liquid electrolytes continuously react with electrodes at maximum cell voltages and upon cycling, causing reduced lifetime through impedance rise and capacity fade. In contrast, polymer electrolytes limit the mobility of reactive electrolyte species, forming solid interfaces that can remain stable over long periods of time and over many charge/discharge cycles. Remarkably, this drastic enhancement in interfacial stability can yield extremely low rates of degradation and capacity fade, even in cells employing otherwise reactive high energy electrodes. Before the widespread commercialization of lithium ion batteries, solid polymer electrolyte technology was considered to be among the most promising routes to enabling lithium-based batteries. However, despite strong government and private-sector funding, academic and commercial efforts to develop batteries based on solid polymer electrolytes consistently failed. At the heart of each of these failures lay the inability to overcome a single fundamental constraint. Ion transport in polymers is coupled to the motion of the surrounding molecules that are solvating the ions. The presence of mobile molecules is thus essential to allow for a conductive medium; however, the same mobility of molecules is detrimental to the polymer's structural integrity. In all cases, polymer electrolytes with high ionic conductivity failed due to mechanical reasons while mechanically robust ion conductors were severely limited in conductivity. At Seeo, we have employed advanced self-assembled polymer nanostructures to break free from this principal constraint. We are commercializing our proprietary polymeric electrolytes in lithium-based batteries for electric vehicle and grid-tied storage applications. I believe my four-year experience leading an industrial research and development team gives me a unique understanding of how to create an academic research program with capabilities of exploratory science, intellectual property generation, and translation to practical application.

Authors: Casas N., Schell J., Joss L., Pini R., Blom R., Mazzotti M.
Title: Characterization of novel adsorbent materials for a CO 2 capture pressure swing adsorption process
Affiliations: Institute for Process Engineering, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich, ETHZ, Zurich, Switzerland; Energy Resources Engineering Department, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; Hydrocarbon Process Chemistry Department, SINTEF Materials and Chemistry, Oslo, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Casas, N., Institute for Process Engineering, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich, ETHZ, Zurich, Switzerland; Schell, J., Institute for Process Engineering, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich, ETHZ, Zurich, Switzerland; Joss, L., Institute for Process Engineering, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich, ETHZ, Zurich, Switzerland; Pini, R., Energy Resources Engineering Department, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; Blom, R., Hydrocarbon Process Chemistry Department, SINTEF Materials and Chemistry, Oslo, Norway; Mazzotti, M., Institute for Process Engineering, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich, ETHZ, Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: Pressure swing adsorption (PSA) is regarded as a promising technology for pre-combustion CO 2 capture, due to the boundary conditions of the separation process (high feed pressure of 35 to 40 bar and high CO 2 feed concentration of about 40%). At the same time, metal organic frameworks have attracted research interest because of their exceptional adsorption properties and their flexibility in tailoring. This work aims at assessing the potential of a metal organic framework (USO-2-Ni) with respect to the performance in separating CO 2 from H 2 in a pressure swing adsorption pre-combustion process. This is done by comparing it to a base case which was designed using commercial activated carbon as adsorbent. Both experimental and theoretical aspects related to the PSA process are investigated in this study. First a sound characterization of the two adsorbents namely activated carbon (Chemviron, Germany) and MOF is done by measuring equilibrium adsorption isotherms of CO 2, H 2 and N 2 using a Magnetic Suspension Balance (Rubotherm, Germany). Additionally physical material properties such as material and bed densities as well as heat capacities were defined. Secondly kinetic parameters, such as mass and heat transfer parameters, are determined by conducting breakthrough experiments. The interpretation of the dynamic experiments is done by describing the process with a detailed one-dimensional model consisting of mass and heat balances and several constitutive equations such as adsorption isotherms, equation of state and pressure drop correlation. The model was further validated by predicting breakthrough curves in a broad temperature and pressure range and compared to the experiments. The comparison of the results of the aforementioned experiments with simulations allowed to confirm the static adsorption measurements and to determine the rapid adsorption kinetics of CO 2 on USO-2-Ni. For the design of the PSA process several aspects are important: the energy penalty has to be minimized whereas the capture rate is aimed to be higher than 90% and the CO 2 purity has to meet the specifications for the subsequent transportation and storage. Therefore after the validation of the process parameters, the simulation tool is used to describe various complete PSA cycles with different combinations of the individual steps. To assess the performance of the newly developed PSA cycles a multi-objective optimization including the CO 2 capture rate and the CO 2 purity is conducted. The results of the PSA simulations considering USO-2-Ni as adsorbent have been compared to those considering an activated carbon adsorbent. The former show a slightly better performance, as expected based on the favorable thermodynamics of the metal organic framework material compared to the thermodynamics of the activated carbon. It was shown that high bed and particle porosities can have a negative effect on the process performance, due to the reduced CO 2 uptake per unit volume and the increased fluid ratio in the column. It is therefore essential to consider the formulation of the adsorbent as much as the adsorption properties in further process development.

Authors: Goldsmith C.F.
Title: Homogeneous/heterogeneous chemistry in energy conversion
Affiliations: Inorganic Chemistry Department, Fritz Haber Institute of the Max Planck Society, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Goldsmith, C.F., Inorganic Chemistry Department, Fritz Haber Institute of the Max Planck Society, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: Hydrocarbon fuels will remain the energy storage medium of choice for the foreseeable future. As the global demand for these fuels increases, sustainable technologies for both the production and consumption of these fuels will become critical. A suit of reforming processes can be used to synthesize liquid fuels from various feed stocks, such as biomass or natural gas. Examples of intermediate processes include short-contact time partial oxidation, oxidative coupling, hydrothermal reforming, and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Advanced conversion technologies - such as homogeneous-charge compression ignition, catalytic combustion, and solid oxide fuel cells - could generate power with increased efficiency. In order to make these technologies both sustainable and commercially viable, we must understand how the chemical bonds in these fuels are manipulated at the atomic level. Unfortunately, the chemistry of energy conversion is staggeringly complex. Most of these technologies involve high temperatures and high pressures. Under these conditions, homogeneous gas-phase chemistry is coupled with heterogeneous surface-phase chemistry. A detailed mechanism for combustion of comparatively small hydrocarbons requires hundreds of species and thousands of reactions, and the inclusion of surface chemistry dramatically increases the complexity. My research will help to elucidate the complex chemistry of energy conversion. I will combine various computational methods with experimental techniques to create and validate kinetic mechanisms in homogeneous/heterogeneous coupled systems. Gas-phase mechanisms will be generated using an automatic reaction mechanism generator, RMG. Thermodynamically consistent surface mechanisms will be generated using scaling relationships, BEP relations, and other methods. Spatial profile reactors will provide experimental data under industrially relevant conditions. The simplified flow field, wide range of operating conditions, and sub-mm resolution of these instruments make them ideal candidates for evaluating microkinetic models. Sensitivity, flux, and reaction-path analyses will highlight which minima and saddle points on a potential energy surface are most important, and these stationary points will be refined with computational quantum chemistry (e.g. DFT) and statistical mechanics. New experiments will be performed to highlight certain reaction channels. This process is iterated until the mechanism is suitably accurate. Finally, mechanism reduction techniques will be applied to create a skeletal mechanism that can be combined with CFD codes for industrial applications.

Authors: Van Nguyen T., Kreutzer H.
Title: Hydrogen-bromine flow battery for large-scale electrical energy storage
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS 66045, United States
Authors with affiliations: Van Nguyen, T., Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS 66045, United States; Kreutzer, H., Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS 66045, United States
Abstract: A suitable electrical energy storage system enables to make full use of the full capacity of renewable energy sources, e.g., wind and solar, and to use existing electrical energy generation and transmission infrastructures. The hydrogen-bromine flow battery is a great candidate for this application because of its very fast reaction kinetics, high energy storage capacity, and high reliability. Areas that need to be overcome to make the commercialization of this system possible include low-cost, durable, and highly active electrocatalysts; low-cost, durable, and highly-permselective membranes; and electrodes and cell designs that minimize transport resistance. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 2011 AIChE Annual Meeting (Minneapolis, MN 10/16-21/2011).

Authors: Havran V., Dudukovic M.P., Lo C.S.
Title: Catalytic conversion of methane and carbon dioxide to higher value products
Affiliations: Energy, Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Washington University in St. Louis, Saint Louis, MO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Havran, V., Energy, Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Washington University in St. Louis, Saint Louis, MO, United States; Dudukovic, M.P., Energy, Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Washington University in St. Louis, Saint Louis, MO, United States; Lo, C.S., Energy, Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Washington University in St. Louis, Saint Louis, MO, United States
