Title: New polymers for energy applications
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Chemistry Department, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States; Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sun, S.-S., Chemistry Department, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States; Zhang, C., Chemistry Department, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States; Li, R., Chemistry Department, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States; Nguyen, T., Chemistry Department, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States; David, T., Chemistry Department, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States; Sun, S., Chemistry Department, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States, Center for Materials Research, Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA, United States
Abstract: High efficiency and cost effective energy conversion, storage, and delivery could be accomplished via development of certain electro-active polymers with engineered electronic frontier orbitals and solid state morphologies. For instance, development and availability of a series of stable, processable, terminal functionalizable acceptor (n-type) or donor (p-type) conjugated polymers with tailored frontier orbital energy levels (HOMOs/LUMOs) and energy gaps (Eg) is essential for a variety of polymer based donor-acceptor (D/A, or p/n) junction based polymeric optoelectronic or thermoelectric device applications, such as the donor-acceptor block copolymer supramolecular nanostructures for photo or thermal energy conversion, storage, and delivery applications. In this work, a general chemical synthetic approach via difunctionalized and derivatized monomers has been developed to engineer the frontier orbital energy levels, energy gaps, as well as solid state morphologies of a series of conjugated and terminal functionalized polymer blocks, and the donor-acceptor coupled block copolymer supramolecular systems for energy applications.

Authors: Jeong J.H., Haan J., Cha C., Chu D., Kong H.
Title: Poly(amino acid)s-mediated synthesis of spatially organized Pt nanoparticles
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Department of Chemistry, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jeong, J.H., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States, Department of Chemistry, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Haan, J., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States, Department of Chemistry, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Cha, C., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States, Department of Chemistry, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Chu, D., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States, Department of Chemistry, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Kong, H., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States, Department of Chemistry, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
Abstract: Nanometer-sized noble metal particles are being increasingly studied for use in various applications including photochemistry, electrochemistry, optics, and catalysis. Recently, extensive efforts have been made to improve nanoparticle dispersion to enhance its performance using various surfactants, dendrimers and polyelectrolytes which can tune colloidal interactions. However, it is still challenging to establish a technology in which spatial organization of metal nanoparticles is finely controlled at varied length scales. Here we present that in situ sol-gel polymerization of metal precursors incorporated into self-assembling poly(amino acid) nanostructure would generate metal nanoparticles with regular spacing at the nanometer scale. This hypothesis was examined using poly(amino acid)s substituted with alkyl chains to form various morphologies from a spherical micelle to a bilayer structure. Platinum precursors (K2PtCl4) were mixed with alkyl-substituted poly(amino acid)s solution followed by reduction to activate sol-gel polymerization to form Pt particles. Specifically, alkyl-substituted poly(amino acid)s with DS of 5 % were assembled into a vesicle with an average diameter of 100 nm, and also presented Pt nanoparticles with diameter of 2 to 5 nm exclusively within a bilayer of the vesicle. Furthermore, the resulting Pt nanoparticles showed a significantly enhanced electro-catalytic activity as compared with Pt particles polymerized via bulk sol-gel polymerization. Taken together, the results of this study demonstrated that the size and spacing of metallic particle can be controlled using a self-assembling polymeric template. The resulting particles present strong potentials to significantly improve performance of a variety of energy storage and generation systems.

Authors: Baumann T., Worsley M., Satcher Jr. J.
Title: Novel carbon aerogel architectures for energy storage applications
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Physical and Life Sciences Directorate, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baumann, T., Physical and Life Sciences Directorate, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Worsley, M., Physical and Life Sciences Directorate, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Satcher Jr., J., Physical and Life Sciences Directorate, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States
Abstract: Carbon aerogels (CAs) are a unique class of porous materials that hold technological promise for a variety of applications, including catalysis, adsorption and energy storage. The utility of these materials is derived from their high surface areas, electrically conductive frameworks and tunable porosities. In addition, the flexibility associated with CA synthesis allows for the incorporation of modifiers, such as carbon nanotubes or metal nanoparticles, that can potentially enhance the thermal, electrical, mechanical or catalytic properties of the aerogel. In this presentation, we will discuss our recent efforts in the design of new CA architectures for use in a range of energy-related technologies, including hydrogen storage, catalysis, batteries and electrochemical actuators. These efforts were supported in part by DOE through the Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy program.

Authors: Xu T., Gordin M.L., Wang D.
Title: Syntheses and characterization of graphene-metal oxide nanocomposites for energy storage applications
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Nuclear, Pennsylvania State University, State College, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Xu, T., Department of Mechanical and Nuclear, Pennsylvania State University, State College, PA, United States; Gordin, M.L., Department of Mechanical and Nuclear, Pennsylvania State University, State College, PA, United States; Wang, D., Department of Mechanical and Nuclear, Pennsylvania State University, State College, PA, United States
Abstract: Graphite has been widely used in catalysis, combustion, and other energy-related technologies. Recent years see graphene, a mono-atomic layer carbon atoms derived from graphite, attracting great attention for its potential to improve performance in these applications due to its large surface area, high chemical stability, excellent electrical and mechanical properties, and potentially much lower manufacturing cost compared to nanostructures like carbon nanotubes. Here we will present the syntheses and characterization of graphene-metal oxide nanocomposites and their electrochemical performance in energy storage applications. The metal oxide nanoparticles were synthesized and simultaneously self-assembled with dispersed graphene into graphene-metal oxide nanocomposites. The nancomposites were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM) and other techniques. Conductivities were measured using impedance spectroscopy. Furthermore, when used as electrode materials in energy storage devices, the nanocomposites showed much-improved charge-discharge performance.

Authors: Li W., Tan C., Lowe M.A., Abruna H.D., Ralph D.C.
Title: Fabrication and electrochemical characterizations of single-layer graphene devices
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Physics Department, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Li, W., Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States, Physics Department, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Tan, C., Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States, Physics Department, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Lowe, M.A., Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States, Physics Department, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Abruna, H.D., Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States, Physics Department, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Ralph, D.C., Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States, Physics Department, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States
Abstract: Graphene has been studied extensively because of its remarkable electrical, mechanical, and optical properties. Integration of graphene into devices brings it one step closer to applications in nanotechnology. The advancement in graphene fabrication by chemical vapor deposition allowed us to explore single-layer graphene. Here, we present the fabrication and characterization of single-layer graphene devices of micrometer to millimeter scale. We show, for the first time, that single-layer graphene devices can be used as working electrodes for electrochemical applications. We extended the study by investigating the functionalization by van der Waals interaction of single-layer graphene with a series of molecules using cyclic voltammetry and Raman spectroscopy. These characterizations provided us a better understanding of the graphene surface and graphene-molecule interface which enable new strategies for energy storage, selective sensing, and information storage and processing.

Authors: Liu D.-J., Yuan S., Goenaga G., Yang J., White D., Mason A.
Title: Exploring application of nanomaterials for fuel cell and hydrogen storage
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Chemical Sciences and Engineering Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, D.-J., Chemical Sciences and Engineering Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States; Yuan, S., Chemical Sciences and Engineering Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States; Goenaga, G., Chemical Sciences and Engineering Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States; Yang, J., Chemical Sciences and Engineering Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States; White, D., Chemical Sciences and Engineering Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States; Mason, A., Chemical Sciences and Engineering Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen storage system and fuel cell stack represent the two most important components in H2-powered fuel cell vehicles. At present, each technology faces its own challenges. For example, for practical applications, the on-board hydrogen storage system must meet the targets set by U.S. DOE on gravimetric/volumetric densities and the cost ($2/kWh) by 2015. These requirements pose significant challenges to a storage material development. For hydrogen to electric energy conversion, the proton exchange membrane fuel cell is the device of the choice. Major technology barriers include the electrode catalyst cost and durability in PEMFC stack. In this presentation, we will discuss our recent progresses in developing nano-porous organic polymers as new H2 adsorbents and aligned carbon nanotubes as novel electrode support for PEMFC. The preparation of these nanomaterials and their impact to the system performance will be provided. Furthermore, their structure-property relationships will be discussed from various characterization studies.

Authors: Long J.W., Chervin C.N., Brandell N.L., Wallace J.M., Rolison D.R.
Title: Functionalized carbon nanofoam electrode architectures as cathodes for Zn-air and Li-air batteries
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Code 6170, Surface Chemistry Branch, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States; Nova Research, Inc., Alexandria, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Long, J.W., Code 6170, Surface Chemistry Branch, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States, Nova Research, Inc., Alexandria, VA, United States; Chervin, C.N., Code 6170, Surface Chemistry Branch, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States, Nova Research, Inc., Alexandria, VA, United States; Brandell, N.L., Code 6170, Surface Chemistry Branch, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States, Nova Research, Inc., Alexandria, VA, United States; Wallace, J.M., Code 6170, Surface Chemistry Branch, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States, Nova Research, Inc., Alexandria, VA, United States; Rolison, D.R., Code 6170, Surface Chemistry Branch, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States, Nova Research, Inc., Alexandria, VA, United States
Abstract: We have developed fiber-paper-supported carbon nanofoams that serve as the basis for multifunctional electrode architectures, with the goal of enhancing the performance of various electrochemical energy storage and conversion devices. Carbon nanofoam substrates are size-scalable (in thickness and electrode footprint) on the macroscale, and exhibit size-tunable pore-solid networks (10-1000 nm) that can be selected for specific applications. We have recently explored nanofoam-based structures as cathodes for metal-air batteries and demonstrated multiple strategies for incorporating electrocatalytic functionalities within the electrode nanoarchitecture. Highly active air cathodes based on manganese oxide (MnOx) catalysts are synthesized via self-limiting electroless deposition at the carbon surfaces to yield conformal, nanoscale MnOx coatings that permeate the macroscopic thickness of pre-formed carbon nanofoam substrates. Electrocatalytic metal nanoparticles (Pd, Pt, Au, or Ag) are readily adsorbed onto thiophene-like functionalities that have been grafted into the carbon nanofoam walls. We present preliminary electrochemical characterization of nanofoam-based air cathodes when used in either aqueous alkaline Zn-air cells or nonaqueous, rechargeable Li-air cells.

Authors: Suga T., Nishide H.
Title: Redox-active radical polymers for rapid charge-storage and -transport
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Applied Chemistry, Waseda University, Japan; Research Institute for Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Suga, T., Department of Applied Chemistry, Waseda University, Japan, Research Institute for Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Japan; Nishide, H., Department of Applied Chemistry, Waseda University, Japan, Research Institute for Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Japan
Abstract: Radical polymers bearing a high density of unpaired electrons in a pendant, non-conjugated fashion on each repeating unit provided a rapid, reversible, and quantitative redox behavior in an electrode form. Careful selection of radicals (TEMPO, galvinoxyl, and nitronylnitroxide, etc.) produced remarkably stable p- and n-type redox couples, which lead to the totally organic-based rechargeable batteries. The power-rate performance of these cells was excellent (360 C rate, 10 sec charge/discharge), as a result of the simple, rapid redox process of the organic radical moieties with no associated structural change in the amorphous polymer layer. Organic polymer-based electrodes are amenable to roll-to-roll or inkjet processing, which allowed the fabrication of a flexible, paper-like, and transparent rechargeable energy-storage device, which could be embedded in radio-frequency identification tags, smart cards and electronic paper.

Authors: Balik R.
Title: Challenges facing the investment environment for natural resource based companies
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: GreenFire Energy, GreenFire Partners, LLC, Salt Lake City, UT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Balik, R., GreenFire Energy, GreenFire Partners, LLC, Salt Lake City, UT, United States
Abstract: GreenFire Energy is pioneering the use of CO2 for electric power generation, grid-scale energy storage, and energy management. Called CO2E™, GreenFire's technologies combine CO2 with geothermal resources to generate renewable, baseload power from pressure and heat, while creating more efficient use of the power grid. GreenFire's initial source of CO2 for technology development is an inexpensive, natural resource, yet financing the development of this potentially beneficial technology has proved challenging. For this discussion, GreenFire Energy will present its technology, the natural resource components, and the financing needs and challenges. CO2E™ captures heat and pressure by circulating either natural or anthropogenic CO2 through hot geologic formations, then returning it to the surface for power generation. The technology can be used to generate baseload power or to store energy to meet peak demand requirements. When used for energy storage, its projected response time to peak energy output is less than two minutes, which is far better than competing technologies. This is an extraordinarily flexible combination that, in effect, constitutes energy supply "on demand" for the grid. No other technology provides this range of capabilities. More importantly, the projected CO2E™ cost of production is the lowest of any scalable technology. CO2E™ is attractive because it makes geothermal power production and energy storage commercially viable over vast portions of the earth at costs lower than for existing technologies. If the technical issues are surmounted, CO2E™ will become the low-cost, high-volume supplier in the enormous electrical power market. CO2E™ has the potential to decrease the cost of geothermal power and greatly increase its output. This can revolutionize the entire electrical power market because it is modeled to have a lower production cost, can be used in many more locations, and generates power from both pressure and heat.

Authors: Charles N.G., Rosmus J., Roper E.D., Evanseck J.D.
Title: Alternative fuels: Metal hexahydrate catalysis of ammonia borane hydroylsis
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Lincoln University, PA, United States; Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Duquesne University, Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Charles, N.G., Department of Chemistry, Lincoln University, PA, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Duquesne University, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Rosmus, J., Department of Chemistry, Lincoln University, PA, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Duquesne University, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Roper, E.D., Department of Chemistry, Lincoln University, PA, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Duquesne University, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Evanseck, J.D., Department of Chemistry, Lincoln University, PA, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Duquesne University, Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Abstract: Ammonia borane (AB) is a target for hydrogen storage media in commercial vehicle hydrogen fuel cells. In our previous work, we have shown agreement between experimental rates of acid catalyzed AB hydrolysis and activation energies from SN2 pathways between hydronium and methylated AB using density functional theory. In similar reactions, precious metals in the form of nanoparticles are known to be powerful catalysts for AB hydrolysis, yet the mechanism is not known. We assume that the nanoparticles are in equilibrium with the metal hexahydrates. In our investigation, we determine how hexahydrates of precious and nonprecious metals influence the structure and energies of AB hydrolysis using density functional theory and ab initio theory. The influence of the hexahydrates of nickel, cobalt, copper, and palladium upon the SN2 reaction path of AB hydrolysis is reported.

Authors: Kelley S.S.
Title: How can bioenergy be made sustainable?
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Forest Biomaterials, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kelley, S.S., Department of Forest Biomaterials, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC, United States
Abstract: Biomass can be used to produce a range seemingly infinite of energy products that can replace fossil fuel base-products. But currently the economics of the conversion processes are challenging, and demonstrating sustainability is daunting. Dollars are used to keep 'score' in the economic game. Life cycle analysis is a reasonable tool for keeping 'score' in the sustainability game, but it still has many challenges. Measuring the sustainability of bioenergy systems has two groups of challenges. First, the large scale production of bioenergy feedstocks by definition requires large land areas, which are by their nature highly variable in terms of biomass productivity, establishment inputs, collection and harvesting, and supply and storage systems, all of which are required for year round operation of a bioenergy production process. With these wide variations in biomass production and collection systems there are additional complications of limited data sets, and significant improvements on specific technical challenges, that both result in few analyses being conducted with the same biomass feedstock assumptions. Even for widely deployed biomass resources, such as the tens of millions of acres of plantation pines, oil seed crops, or corn stover, there is a limited understanding of how effectively these commercial systems can be extended to the less productive or marginal lands that must be used to avoid the competition with the food supply. Nevertheless, it is clear that chemical inputs at establishment, transportation distances, and the losses and compositional changes during storage all have a significant impact on the feedstock portion of a LCA.

Authors: Stenger-Smith J.D.
Title: Electroactive polymers: From corrosion conversion coatings to burst power storage and delivery
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Research Department, US Navy China Lake, NAWCWD, China Lake, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stenger-Smith, J.D., Research Department, US Navy China Lake, NAWCWD, China Lake, CA, United States
Abstract: The area of conductive/electroactive polymers, pioneered in a large part by Prof. Lenz, has both realized successes and tremendous future potential application. In the first part of the talk, the 12-year history of a project that involved the replacement of Chromium VI with a electroactive polymeric material, Poly(bis-N-hexyl, N-methyl amino-(phenylene vinylene)) (BAMPPV) for aluminum conversion coatings will be reviewed. Results from first small scale synthesis up through and including current field testing will be presented, as well as other applications of this material. In the second part of the talk, the current state-of-the-art of electroactive polymer supercapacitors will be examined and discussed. The design parameters and potential output (peak power and energy) of a hybrid battery/supercapacitor system will be evaluated in terms of the duty cycle for several battery systems. The power and energy output limits of a hybrid device will be presented.

Authors: Koech P.K., Heldebrant D.J., Lee S.-J., Rainbolt J.E., Smurthwaite T.D.
Title: Synthesis, characterization and application of alkanolamidines and alkanolguanidines in CO2 capture
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Energy and Efficiency Division, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koech, P.K., Energy and Efficiency Division, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Heldebrant, D.J., Energy and Efficiency Division, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Lee, S.-J., Energy and Efficiency Division, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Rainbolt, J.E., Energy and Efficiency Division, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Smurthwaite, T.D., Energy and Efficiency Division, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Abstract: Global carbon dioxide (CO2) emission to the atmosphere is partly responsible for climate change. In order to mitigate these environmental effects CO2 capture and storage is required. Solvents currently used for this application are the energy intensive aqueous amines. Here we present the synthesis, characterization and CO2 uptake of new advanced solvents called alkanolamidines and alkanolguanidines otherwise known as CO2-binding organic Liquids (CO2BOLs). These solvents have been designed to have decreased vapor pressure and low viscosity in order to increase the CO2 uptake capacity while minimizing evaporative losses. Alkanolamidines were synthesized in 1-3 steps from commercially available materials. These compounds bind CO2 chemically via the alcohol moiety forming zwitterionic alkylcarbonates. The alkanolamidines can be regenerated thermally by heating the alkylcarbonate to 75 °C. CO2 binding capacities up to 10 wt% were achieved using these compounds. These compounds have the potential to be energy efficient CO2 capture solvents.

Authors: Lee J., Kim U.S., Burm C., Sung S., Kim T., Lee J.
Title: Modeling of the charge-discharge behaviors of a valve-regulated lead-acid battery
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Ajou University, Suwon, South Korea; Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, J., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ajou University, Suwon, South Korea, Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea; Kim, U.S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ajou University, Suwon, South Korea, Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea; Burm, C., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ajou University, Suwon, South Korea, Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea; Sung, S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ajou University, Suwon, South Korea, Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea; Kim, T., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ajou University, Suwon, South Korea, Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea; Lee, J., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ajou University, Suwon, South Korea, Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea
Abstract: Transportation is one of the largest sources of human-induced greenhouse gas emissions and fossil-fuels consumption. This has led to a growing demand for hybrid-electric vehicles (HEVs) to reduce air pollution and consumption of fossil fuels. But hybrid-electric vehicles demand the battery to be discharged and charged at high rates under partial-state-of-charge condition. At present, candidates for the energy-storage systems in HEV applications are valve-regulated lead-acid (VRLA), nickel-metal-hydride (Ni-MH) and rechargeable lithium batteries. The VRLA battery has advantages in terms of relatively low cost, high charge efficiency and safety compared to the other batteries. In this study, a one-dimensional modeling was carried-out to calculate the charge and discharge behaviors of VRLA battery used in HEVs. The model accounts for electrochemical reaction rates, charge conservation and mass transport. In order to validate the model, modeling results were compared with the experimental data in various conditions.

Authors: Thompson C.J., Loring J.S., Wang Z., Joly A.G., Rosso K.M., Felmy A.R.
Title: In situ infrared spectroscopic study of the reactivity of forsterite, antigorite, and lizardite in dry to water-saturated supercritical CO2
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, C.J., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Loring, J.S., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Wang, Z., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Joly, A.G., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Rosso, K.M., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States; Felmy, A.R., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Abstract: Long-term storage of CO2 in deep geologic formations has significant potential for reducing energy- and industrial-sector emissions of CO2 into the atmosphere. The chemical reactions between reservoir sediments and supercritical CO2 (scCO2) containing water, however, are not well understood. In this work, we used in situ infrared spectroscopy to investigate the carbonation of representative olivine (forsterite) and serpentine (antigorite and lizardite) minerals. Experiments were conducted by circulating a stream of dry or wet scCO2 past a mineral overlayer deposited on the window of a high-pressure infrared flow cell. Little reaction was observed when the minerals were exposed to dry scCO2 for 24 hr. When water was added, a thin film of liquid-like water was observed on the mineral surface, and a carbonation reaction occurred. The extent of carbonation appeared to be dependent on both the film thickness and the mineral. Forsterite was significantly more reactive than antigorite and lizardite.

Authors: Nocera D.G.
Title: Multielectron excited state and hydrogen production
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nocera, D.G., Department of Chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Abstract: All reactions of energy consequence require the transfer of two or more electrons. This is true for the photochemical production of hydrogen. We have designed ligands that enforce a two-electron excited state electronic structure on bimetallic centers. From this platform, both a rational two-electron hydrogen photochemistry may be developed. This talk will present results along this vein, and then show how authentic solar energy storage may be achieved by closing the photocycle.

Authors: Zhang Y.-H.P.
Title: Starch production through artificial photosynthesis mediated by cell-free synthetic enzymatic pathway
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Biological Systems Engineering Department, Virginia Tech., Blacksburg, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Y.-H.P., Biological Systems Engineering Department, Virginia Tech., Blacksburg, VA, United States
Abstract: A number of biofuels have been investigated for the transportation sector. Hydrogen plus fuel cells is believed to be the best combination in the future. According to our previous breakthrough - complete conversion of carbohydrate and water to hydrogen and CO2, we propose the use of carbohydrate (e.g., starch) as a high energy density hydrogen carrier with a gravimetric density of 14.8 H2 mass % and suggest sugar fuel cell vehicles. To produce starch without relying on living plants, we design a non-natural CO2 fixation pathway that can fix CO2 by using hydrogen or electricity and produce water insoluble starch. This pathway would be scalable because it involves neither membrane nor membrane protein. A combination of this chemical synthesis pathway with commercial solar cells would have overall solar energy-to-chemical energy efficiencies of more than 20% and decrease water consumption by more than 1000 fold as compared to those of natural plants. This artificial photosynthesis would solve key challenges, such as CO2 fixation, electricity storage, feed and food production, transportation fuel production, water conservation or maintaining an ecosystem for space travel. Therefore, collaborations are urgently needed to solve several technological bottlenecks before its large-scale implementation. Eventually sustainable development requires balanced integration of four basic human needs - air (O2/CO2), water, food, and energy.

Authors: Chervin C.N., Long J.W., Rolison D.R.
Title: Nanoparticulate RuO2 dispersed on paper-like substrates for energy storage and conversion
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chervin, C.N., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States; Long, J.W., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States; Rolison, D.R., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States
Abstract: Ruthenium dioxide (RuO2) is a technologically important electrocatalytic material used extensively in the chloralkali industry for chlorine production from brine and investigated for energy storage and conversion applications including water oxidation (hydrogen production), electrochemical capacitors, direct methanol fuel cell catalysts (when combined with platinum), and Li-ion insertion electrodes. The cost of RuO2 precursors limits these and other applications, which has prompted development of highly dispersed, nanoscale forms of the oxide that maximize the number of catalytically active reaction sites while minimizing weight loading. In order to prepare highly-active, 3D electrode architectures with low loadings of RuO2, we have developed a simple solution-based synthesis in which self-wired networks of RuO2 deposit onto porous, paper-like substrates including commercially available SiO2 filter papers (RuO2[SiO2]) or in-house fabricated carbon nanofoam papers (RuO2[nanofoam]). On SiO2 filter papers the RuO2 forms a contiguous, nanoskin of 2-3-nm RuO2 particles wrapped around the individual fibers composing the paper. The RuO2 network imparts high electronic conductivity and electrochemical activity to the otherwise insulating SiO2 paper at only 5 wt% RuO2. Because the oxide coating is virtually all surface (90% of the RuO2 in a 2-nm particle is surface-sited) the utilization of this expensive catalyst is maximized. In contrast to the insulating, macroporous SiO2 filter paper, the high-surface-area carbon nanofoams express a through-connected network of size-tunable pores (10s to 100s of nm) and high electronic conductivity, thus providing a pre-formed nanoarchitecture to distribute the nanoparticulate RuO2. Here we present synthesis and characterization of the RuO2[SiO2] and RuO2[nanofoam] papers and their electrocatalytic activity with respect to energy storage and conversion applications.

Authors: Zeitler E.L., Morris A.J., Lakkaraju P.S., Barton Cole E., Bocarsly A.B.
Title: Aromatic amine electrocatalysts for the coupling of CO2 to form multicarbon alcohols: Electrode surface and substituent effects
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States; Liquid Light, Inc., Monmouth Junction, NJ, United States; Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Georgian Court University, Lakewood, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zeitler, E.L., Department of Chemistry, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States, Liquid Light, Inc., Monmouth Junction, NJ, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Georgian Court University, Lakewood, NJ, United States; Morris, A.J., Department of Chemistry, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States, Liquid Light, Inc., Monmouth Junction, NJ, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Georgian Court University, Lakewood, NJ, United States; Lakkaraju, P.S., Department of Chemistry, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States, Liquid Light, Inc., Monmouth Junction, NJ, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Georgian Court University, Lakewood, NJ, United States; Barton Cole, E., Department of Chemistry, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States, Liquid Light, Inc., Monmouth Junction, NJ, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Georgian Court University, Lakewood, NJ, United States; Bocarsly, A.B., Department of Chemistry, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States, Liquid Light, Inc., Monmouth Junction, NJ, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Georgian Court University, Lakewood, NJ, United States
Abstract: The energy efficient reduction of CO2 to multicarbon fuels represents an important opportunity in energy storage and greenhouse gas mitigation. It has previously been noted that the pyridinium catalyzed reduction of CO2 to methanol at platinum electrodes provides superior reaction kinetics. Prior work on this system indicates that the formation of methanol requires surface dependent processes. Presented here is an exploration of nickel chromium alloy electrodes as well as new pyridinium derived catalysts for carbon-carbon bond formation from CO2. Nickel chromium alloy electrodes show formation of ethanol and isopropanol upon reduction of CO2 in the presence of pyridinium, a chemistry that does not occur at simple platinum group metal electrodes. Surface preparation of the nickel chromium electrodes affects the potential at which catalysis takes place. The mechanism by which carbon-carbon bond formation occurs will be considered in this presentation.

Authors: Wang H., Liang Y., Sanchez H., Yang Y., Cui L.-F., Cui Y., Dai H.
Title: Graphene-based hybrid nanomaterials for energy storage applications
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, H., Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States, Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; Liang, Y., Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States, Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; Sanchez, H., Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States, Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; Yang, Y., Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States, Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; Cui, L.-F., Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States, Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; Cui, Y., Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States, Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States; Dai, H., Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States, Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, United States
Abstract: We have developed a two step solution phase method to selectively synthesize nanocrystals of oxide and hydroxide on graphene sheets. The morphology and size of the nanocrystals grown on graphene can be readily tuned by synthetic parameters. The hybrid nanomaterials showed high electrochemical performance for supercapacitors and lithium ion batteries, as a result of the intimate interactions between the active materials and the highly conducting graphene network, and the desired morphology and size of the nanocrysstals on graphene.

Authors: Gordin M.L., Chen Z., Xu T., Wang D.
Title: Synthesis and characterization of ordered mesoporous metal oxide-carbon nanocomposites and their applications in supercapacitors
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Mechanical and Nuclear Engineering, Penn State University, University Park, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gordin, M.L., Mechanical and Nuclear Engineering, Penn State University, University Park, PA, United States; Chen, Z., Mechanical and Nuclear Engineering, Penn State University, University Park, PA, United States; Xu, T., Mechanical and Nuclear Engineering, Penn State University, University Park, PA, United States; Wang, D., Mechanical and Nuclear Engineering, Penn State University, University Park, PA, United States
Abstract: High surface area conductive carbon materials with tailored pore structures and porosity are highly desirable for many applications such as fuel cells, electrochemical energy storage in supercapacitors, electrochemical sensing, and catalysis. Many such materials, including activated carbon and multi- and single-walled carbon nanotubes, have been explored for supercapacitors. A higher capacitance can be achieved by surface modification of the carbon materials with redox active materials such as transition metal oxides. Mesoporous carbon/metal oxide composites - composed of a mesoporous carbon framework whose pore walls are lined with metal oxide nanoparticles - are a promising candidate for supercapacitor applications. Most methods of synthesizing such materials are two steps procedures, like coating metal oxide on pre-formed carbon materials. Our group has been working on a one-step process for synthesizing a mesoporous carbon/metal oxide nanocomposite by combining condensation of metal oxide with carbonization of carbon precursors. Here we present a one-step synthesis for ordered mesoporous metal oxide-carbon nanocomposites with uniform mesopore structures. These were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), N2 sorption, transmission electron microscope (TEM), and other techniques. Electrochemical double layer capacitance has been measured in the nanocomposites and compared with pure carbon and metal oxide materials to illustrate their synergetic capacitance improvement.

Authors: Ma Z., Dardas Z.
Title: Effect of membrane pore structure on water vapor transport at solid/gas/liquid interfaces
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Physical Sciences, United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ma, Z., Department of Physical Sciences, United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT, United States; Dardas, Z., Department of Physical Sciences, United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT, United States
Abstract: Polymeric membranes have been widely used in many applications. One example related to energy storage is the use of porous membrane based enthalpy exchangers (with concentration storage) in air conditioning systems. For example, liquid desiccant (LD) can be concentrated during day time by solar thermal energy and stored for later use to absorb moisture (dehumidification) from the process air through a membrane based AIR/LD contactor. This can achieve independent humidity control and as high as 30% energy savings. However, liquid desiccant carryover has been a major obstacle in the application of existing LD dehumidification technologies to air conditioning due to the corrosion of ductwork over the time and the potential toxicity of LD aerosols or droplets introduced into the conditioned air. The use of porous membrane isolates the LD from contacting air, therefore, eliminating the potential of LD carryover. Usually, hydrophobic membrane is used, the hydrophobic material and proper pore morphologies can prevent LD from entering the membrane pores while allows water vapor transported across the membrane (see Figure 1b). The introduction of the membrane demands a more detailed understanding of the pore structure on transport. This paper will focus on the effect of morphological structure on vapor transport at solid/gas/liquid interfaces as shown in Figure 1b.

Authors: Bowden M., Karkamkar A., Kim H., Cho H., Hess N., Autrey T.
Title: Experimental approaches to study the properties of energy storage materials in nanoconfined environments: Modification of ammonia borane in porous silica
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, United States; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Bowden, M., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, United States, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Japan; Karkamkar, A., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, United States, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Japan; Kim, H., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, United States, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Japan; Cho, H., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, United States, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Japan; Hess, N., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, United States, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Japan; Autrey, T., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, United States, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Japan
Abstract: We have investigated Ammonia borane (AB, NH3BH3) for its promising hydrogen storage potential (19.6 wt% H2) and compared its properties in the bulk form to those when infiltrated into the nanopores (4-10 nm diameter) of MCM-41 or SBA-15. Confinement of AB in nanoporous silica had a dramatic effect on H2 release, lowering the release temperature by 20°C, reaction enthalpy by 20 kJ mol-1, and also the concentration of borazine impurity. To understand this behaviour we have investigated composites of AB in MCM-41 using a variety of methods including NMR spectroscopy (hyperpolarised 129Xe, solid-state 2H and 11B), X-ray PDF analysis, anelastic spectroscopy, and Raman spectroscopy. We will discuss the results of these experimental studies. PNNL is operated by Battelle.

Authors: Augustyn V., Quickel T., Tolbert S., Dunn B.
Title: Pseudocapacitor properties of nanostructured transition metal oxides
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States; Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Augustyn, V., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States; Quickel, T., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States; Tolbert, S., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States; Dunn, B., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: Capacitive energy storage is distinguished from other types of electrochemical energy storage by short charging times, long cycling life and the ability to deliver high power. A key limitation to this technology is its low energy density and for this reason there is considerable interest in exploring pseudocapacitive charge storage mechanisms. Our research has shown that nanostructured transition metal oxides are a very promising approach for achieving enhanced pseudocapacitance. Using TiO2 as a model system, we find that pseudocapacitive contributions become increasingly important at crystallite sizes below 10 nm, leading to greater amounts of total stored charge without compromising kinetics. We have now extended these studies to mesoporous transition metal oxide films such as TiO2, MoO3 and Nb2O5. With these systems, there is the prospect of designing materials that possess both high energy and high power density.

Authors: Wei B.
Title: Supercapacitors from carbon nanotubes
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wei, B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE, United States
Abstract: Electricity storage is a growing challenge among a broad range of renewable energy sources. Of the many types of rechargeable power sources that are currently being investigated, carbon nanotube-based supercapacitors have attracted much attention due to their capability to generate energy and power densities much higher than conventional dielectric capacitors and lithium ion batteries, respectively. In the meantime, flexible/stretchable electronics have attracted considerable attention very recent years and have opened the door to many important applications that current, rigid electronics cannot achieve. In order to accommodate these needs, power source devices must be flexible and stretchable in addition to their high energy and power density, light weight, miniaturization in size, and safety requirements.

Authors: Lee S.-H., Nam Kim J., Deok Ko Y., Hyun Eom W., Soo Park J., Boo Lee C., Hyun Back I.
Title: Development of hybrid system for pre-combustion CO2 capture
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Gasification Research Group, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, S.-H., Gasification Research Group, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea; Nam Kim, J., Gasification Research Group, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea; Deok Ko, Y., Gasification Research Group, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea; Hyun Eom, W., Gasification Research Group, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea; Soo Park, J., Gasification Research Group, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea; Boo Lee, C., Gasification Research Group, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea; Hyun Back, I., Gasification Research Group, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea
Abstract: As new technologies for energy increase in the world, integrated gasification combined cycle (IGCC) with carbon capture and storage has been developed as a means for maximizing energy efficiency and minimizing the effect of climate change. To make CO2 rich stream and separate hydrogen from reacted gas stream in gasification processes, a hybrid system composed of two step water gas shift reactor and Pd-Cu membrane reactor has been under development. As the partial pressure of hydrogen increased, the hydrogen flux generally increased. CO2 and CO concentration increased with increasing bed pressure because the permeation of H2 increased. When hydrogen permeate flux increased with increasing gas flow, the concentration of CO2 in retentate flow decreased from 84.75vol% to 78.20vol%. In order to maximize CO2 concentration in retentate flow and to use WGS with membrane reactor in pre-combustion CO2 capture, higher pressure and moderate gas flow in membrane reactors may be needed.

Authors: Chen J.
Title: Mn-based oxide nanomaterials as non-noble metal catalysts for electrochemical oxygen reduction
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Institute of New Energy Material Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin, Tianjin, China
Authors with affiliations: Chen, J., Institute of New Energy Material Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin, Tianjin, China
Abstract: Electrochemical energy storage and conversion play an important role in the development of sustainable technologies to mitigate the global warming and lower our dependence on fossil fuels. Fuel cells are the representative electrochemical devices that can convert chemical energy directly into electrical energy with high efficiency and low emission of pollutants. However, the commercialization of fuel cells is severely hampered by the sluggish oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) in the cathode, which demands the exclusive use of Pt-based catalysts. As Pt is expensive and scarce, extensive efforts have focused on improving the catalytic activity of Pt alloys to lower the Pt loading, and more attractively, exploring non-precious metal catalysts. In this context, our group have recently prepared and investigated a series of Mn-based oxide materials for catalyzing the electrochemical ORR. Manganese is featured with virtues of low cost, high abundance, environmental friendliness, and rich redox chemistry, rendering the Mn-based compounds versatile electrochemical properties. We have selectively synthesized MnO2, Mn2O3, MnOOH, and CoMn2O4 with controlled phases and shapes through facile solution-based soft chemistry routes. Our results showed that the electrocatalytic activities of manganese oxides depended strongly on their compositions, crystallographic structures, and morphologies. The nanostructured samples, having prominent advantages of high surface areas and enormous exposed catalytic sites, exhibited significantly higher activity than the counterpart bulk materials. Remarkably, Ni nanoparticles decorated α-MnO2 nanowires and large-aspect-ratio Mn2O3 nanowires could generate a specific ORR current comparable to the Pt/C catalysts and result in an apparent quasi 4-electron transfer per molecular oxygen in alkaline electrolyte. Therefore, the manganese oxide nanomaterials with novel morphologies may find prospective applications as cheap ORR electrocatalysts for alkaline fuel cells and metal-air batteries.

Authors: Marshall A.R., Ostendorf M.L., Madden E.R., Serier K.N., Lytle J.C.
Title: Fabricating porous nanoarchitectures for energy storage
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Chemistry Department, Pacific Lutheran University, Tacoma, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Marshall, A.R., Chemistry Department, Pacific Lutheran University, Tacoma, WA, United States; Ostendorf, M.L., Chemistry Department, Pacific Lutheran University, Tacoma, WA, United States; Madden, E.R., Chemistry Department, Pacific Lutheran University, Tacoma, WA, United States; Serier, K.N., Chemistry Department, Pacific Lutheran University, Tacoma, WA, United States; Lytle, J.C., Chemistry Department, Pacific Lutheran University, Tacoma, WA, United States
Abstract: Several recent articles have contrasting views on the importance of pore geometry in electrochemical double-layer capacitor materials. We hypothesize that the pore geometry of macroporous carbon nanoarchitectures does not affect the magnitude of capacitance or the rate of charge transport within pore networks. To address this question, we fabricate and compare the electrochemical double-layer capacitances of carbon inverse opal fabrics and carbon nanofoam electrodes-two nanomaterials that are otherwise similar except for the periodicity of their pore networks. Both materials are relatively new classes of nanomaterials that have greater mechanical flexibility and electronic conductivity than conventional carbon aerogels and carbon inverse opal monoliths. We will compare the physical and electrochemical properties of both carbon nanoarchitectures. Preliminary evidence based on cyclic voltammetry and impedance spectroscopy indicates that both electrode nanoarchitectures discharge similar amounts of capacitance and enable ionic charge to transport throughout macropore networks in similar durations of time.

Authors: DuBois D.L.
Title: Development of molecular electrocatalysts for hydrogen generation and utilization
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Chemical and Materials Sciences Division, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: DuBois, D.L., Chemical and Materials Sciences Division, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA, United States
Abstract: Catalysts capable of efficient conversion between electrical energy and fuels will be important for a flexible and sustainable energy supply in the future. Renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind, are intermittent and will require large scale energy storage. An attractive approach to storing this energy is the generation of fuels such as hydrogen. In recent work we have developed nickel complexes containing diphosphine ligands with pendant bases as electrocatalysts for hydrogen oxidation and production. The development of these catalysts has been guided by an understanding of the contributions of both the first and second coordination spheres of these catalysts. Pendant bases incorporated in the second coordination sphere of the molecular catalysts for H2 production and oxidation serve as proton relays controlling the movement of protons between the metal and acids or bases in solution. Insights into additional roles played by the pendant bases during the catalytic cycles will be discussed.

Authors: Srivastava D.
Title: Quantum simulations based design and modeling of nano-scale composite cathode materials for high energy density Li-ion battery
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Research and Development, Nanoexa, Corp., Mountain View, CA, United States; Department of Research and Development, UARC, UC Santa Cruz/NASA Ames, Moffett Field, Ca, United States
Authors with affiliations: Srivastava, D., Department of Research and Development, Nanoexa, Corp., Mountain View, CA, United States, Department of Research and Development, UARC, UC Santa Cruz/NASA Ames, Moffett Field, Ca, United States
Abstract: High rate and high energy density lithium ion batteries (LIB) constitute a major requirement for plug-in-hybrid (PHEV) and electric (EV) automotive, and smart- grid related energy storage applications. Year-to-year electrochemical performance improvements in Li-ion batteries are typically limited to within 3-4% unless new electrode materials, chemistries and improvements in them are introduced rapidly. Nanoexa has developed a patent pending ab-initio density functional theory (DFT) level quantum simulations based battery materials database and design technology platform for new LIB electrode materials compositions and morphologies much faster than what is feasible through the current empirical experimental methods. The acceleration of technology innovation and development includes not only the quantum simulated database and materials composition design software but also the experimentally synthesized, characterized, and validated nano-scale compositions and composites for specific capacity, voltage, volume-change on charge and discharge, relative safety and cycling, and electrochemical discharge curves. This talk will describe the basic underlying technology with simulated results and comparison with experimental data, followed by a focus on materials synthesis for nano-scale morphology control and the link to coin-cell level discharge curves for Li-(NCM)-Oxide type composite cathode materials.

Authors: Willgert M., Kjell M.H., Lindbergh G., Johansson M.
Title: Photoinduced polymerization of structural lithium-ion battery electrolytes
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Fibre and Polymer Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden; Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Applied Electrochemistry, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Willgert, M., Department of Fibre and Polymer Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Applied Electrochemistry, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden; Kjell, M.H., Department of Fibre and Polymer Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Applied Electrochemistry, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden; Lindbergh, G., Department of Fibre and Polymer Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Applied Electrochemistry, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden; Johansson, M., Department of Fibre and Polymer Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Applied Electrochemistry, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: The future demand of energy from renewable sources and uses in different applications calls for new solutions to store the energy. As of today, batteries are the primary considered storage medium for electrical energy. Batteries however tend to be of significant weight and also occupy a significant space in a product such as a mobile phone or a car. One way suggested to encounter this problem is to let the battery itself be an integrated part of the construction. This can be achieved by using a thermoset polymer matrix as a load carrying part of the battery electrolyte. The present study describes the use of UV-induced polymerization as a versatile tool to manufacture structural thermoset lithium-ion polymer electrolytes. Several benefits such as rapid production, low thermal impact, and well defined networks are achieved.

Authors: Dillon A.C., Ban C., Riley L.A., Cavanagh A.S., George S.M., Lee S.-H.
Title: Methods to achieve durable high rate with high capacity for Li-ion batteries
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Chemical and Materials Sciences Department, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States; Chemistry Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States; Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dillon, A.C., Chemical and Materials Sciences Department, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States, Chemistry Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States, Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States; Ban, C., Chemical and Materials Sciences Department, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States, Chemistry Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States, Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States; Riley, L.A., Chemical and Materials Sciences Department, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States, Chemistry Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States, Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States; Cavanagh, A.S., Chemical and Materials Sciences Department, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States, Chemistry Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States, Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States; George, S.M., Chemical and Materials Sciences Department, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States, Chemistry Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States, Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States; Lee, S.-H., Chemical and Materials Sciences Department, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States, Chemistry Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States, Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States
Abstract: Significant advances in both energy density and rate capability for Li-ion batteries will be necessary for implementation in next generation electric vehicles. By employing metal oxide nanostructures, it is possible to achieve Li-ion anodes that have significantly higher capacity than the state-of-the-art technology. However, because of the large volume expansion it is difficult to achieve stable cycling. We have demonstrated that thin film MoO3 nanoparticle electrodes (∼2 μm thick) have a stable reversible capacity of ∼630 mAh/g, at C/2 (charge/dicharge in 2 hours). By fabricating more conventional electrodes (∼35 μm thick) with conductive additive and binder, an improved reversible capacity of ∼1000 mAh/g is achieved but, unfortunately, the rate capability decreases. In order to achieve high-rate capability, we applied a thin Al2O3 atomic layer deposition coating to enable high volume expansion and prevent mechanical degradation. Recently we have focused on iron oxide nanostructures, as iron is an inexpensive and non-toxic element. Furthermore, we have synthesized binder-free, high-rate capability electrodes. The electrodes contain Fe3O4 nanorods as the active storage material and carbon single-wall nanotubes (SWNTs) as the conductive additive. The highest reversible capacity is obtained using 5 wt.% SWNTs, reaching ∼1000 mAh/g at C rate when coupled with a lithium metal electrode. Furthermore, the electrodes exhibit high rate capability and stable capacities of 800 mAh/g at 5C (charge/discharge in 12 minutes), sustained over 100 cycles and 600 mAh/g at 10C (charge/discharge in 6 minutes). Scanning electron microscopy indicates the high-rate capability is achieved because Fe3O4 nanorods are uniformly suspended in the SWNT matrix. Raman spectroscopy was employed to understand how the SWNTs function as a highly flexible conductive additive. Recently, we have also employed this method to demonstrate improved conductivity and highly improved rate capability for a LiNi0.4Mn0.4Co0.2O2 cathode material.

Authors: Balkus Jr. K.J.
Title: Metal oxide nanotube films prepared via pulsed laser ablation for energy applications
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Alan G. MacDiarmid Nanotech Institute, University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Balkus Jr., K.J., Department of Chemistry, Alan G. MacDiarmid Nanotech Institute, University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX, United States
Abstract: Recently, nanostructured materials have received greater attention for energy applications due to their distinct electrical and chemical properties, especially in photovoltaic and energy storage devices, which require very high surface areas and energy densities. The fabrication of 1D semiconducting metal oxide nanostructures plays a crucial role in developing alternative energy storage/ conversion devices with high power and energy densities. Low dimensional nanotubular morphologies are particularly attractive, but the preparation of thin films remains a challenge. A novel technique for the preparation of TiO2 and V2O5 nanotube films via pulsed laser deposition (PLD) will be described. A high energy laser beam (248 nm) was demagnified on a metal oxide target, depositing a thin film on the substrate. After PLD a simple hydrothermal treatment was used to grow the nanotubes. High surface area small diameter (<10 nm) TiO2 nanotube (TNT) thin films were grown on stainless steel and Ti foils and then sensitized with dyes and PbS quantum dots. Photovoltaic results using the TNT films will be discussed. V2O5 nanotubes (VNT) (∼50 nm) were prepared on high surface area carbon fiber sheets via the pulsed laser deposition technique. Coin cell type (CR2032) capacitors were assembled with the VNT coated carbon as one electrode and carbon as the other. Capacitance and power density results will be presented. The nanotube films were characterized by TEM, SEM, XRD, FTIR and Raman spectroscopy.

Authors: Sassin M.B., Long J.W., Mansour A.N., Greenbaum S.G., Marie Wallace J., Pettigrew K.A., Rolison D.R.
Title: High-performance electrochemical capacitors enabled by metal-oxide-decorated carbon nanoarchitectures
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Code 6170 Surface, Chemistry Branch, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C., United States; Systems and Materials for Power and Protection Branch, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Carderock Division, West Bethesda, MD, United States; Department of Physics and Astronomy, Hunter College, City University of New York, New York, NY, United States; Nova Research Inc., Alexandria, VA, United States
